[[University of South Carolina]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|joewilson.house.gov|House website}} |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{army|United States}} |serviceyears = 1972–2003{{cite web |url=http://www.ausa.org/legislation/congressionalinfo/Documents/OAS%20112th%20Congress.pdf |title=Once a Soldier ... Always a Soldier |author=Staff |work=Legislative Agenda |publisher=[[Association of the United States Army]] |accessdate=January 28, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021200011/http://www.ausa.org/legislation/congressionalinfo/Documents/OAS%20112th%20Congress.pdf |archivedate=October 21, 2013 |df= }} |rank = [[File:US-O6 insignia.svg|23px]] [[Colonel (United States)|Colonel]] |unit = [[United States Army Reserve]] (1972–1975)
[[South Carolina Army National Guard]] (1975–2003) }} '''Addison Graves''' "'''Joe'''"''' Wilson Sr.''' (born July 31, 1947) is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|SC|2}}, serving since 2001. The district stretches from the state capital, [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia]], to the Georgia-South Carolina border. From 1985 to 2001, he served in the [[South Carolina Senate]]. He is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. He is a member of the [[Steering and Policy Committee of the United States House of Representatives|House Republican Policy Committee]] and is an Assistant Republican [[Whip (politics)|Whip]].{{cite web|url=http://www.joewilson.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=37&Itemid=34 |title=Joe Wilson – Congressman Joe Wilson's Biography |publisher=Joewilson.house.gov |date=July 31, 1947 |accessdate=December 8, 2009}} In September 2009, Wilson received international attention when he interrupted a [[Barack Obama speech to joint session of Congress, September 2009|speech by U.S. President Barack Obama]] to the [[Joint session of the United States Congress|joint session of Congress]] by shouting "You lie!".{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/09/09/joe.wilson/index.html |title=CNN, Politics, retrieved 14 September 2009 |publisher=Cnn.com |date=September 10, 2009 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/americas/2009/09/2009916172057802997.html |title=Carter: Obama a target for racism |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=2009-09-16 |accessdate=October 7, 2010}} The incident [[List of United States Representatives expelled, censured, or reprimanded#Reprimanded Representatives|resulted in a reprimand]] by the House of Representatives.{{cite news|last=Phillips |first=Kate |url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/15/blogging-the-house-action-on-wilson/ |title=House Admonishes Wilson on Outburst|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 9, 2009 |accessdate=August 22, 2011}} Wilson was re-elected in 2010 by 9 percentage points over his closest challenger and when he ran unopposed in the 2012 general election he was re-elected with 96% of the vote. Wilson won re-election in 2014 with more than 62% of the vote in a three-way race. ==Early life, education, and career== Wilson was born in [[Charleston, South Carolina]], the son of Wray (née Graves) and Hugh deVeaux Wilson.{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/reps/wilsonjoe.htm |title=Joe Wilson |website=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-16}} Wilson obtained a bachelor's degree in political science from [[Washington and Lee University]] in 1969 where he joined [[Sigma Nu]],{{cite web|url=http://sigmanu.wlu.edu/famousalum.html |title=Sigma Nu |website=Sigmanu.wlu.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-01-16}} and obtained his [[Juris Doctor]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) degree from the [[University of South Carolina School of Law]] in 1972.{{cite news |url=http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/members/w000795/ |title=Joe Wilson | Congressional votes database |publisher=Projects.washingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=December 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106082505/http://projects.washingtonpost.com/congress/members/w000795/ |archivedate=January 6, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|title=Joe Wilson's Biography|url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/3985/joe-wilson-sr#.VIdSRDHF-Tt|website=Project Vote Smart|accessdate=9 December 2014}} From 1972 to 1975, Wilson served in the [[United States Army Reserve]], and then as a Staff Judge Advocate in the [[South Carolina Army National Guard]] assigned to the [[218th Maneuver Enhancement Brigade|218th Mechanized Infantry Brigade]] until retiring from military service as a [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]] in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.joewilson.house.gov/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=37&Itemid=40 |title=Joe Wilson – Congressman Joe Wilson's Biography |publisher=Joewilson.house.gov |date=July 31, 1947 |accessdate=December 8, 2009}} As a real estate attorney, Wilson co-accounted (with Derek Vinyard) the law firm Kirkland, Wilson, Moore, Taylor & Thomas{{cite web|url=http://www.votesmart.org/bio.php?can_id=3985 |title=Project Vote Smart – Representative Addison Graves 'Joe' Wilson Sr. – Biography |publisher=Votesmart.org |date=July 31, 1947 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} in [[West Columbia, South Carolina|West Columbia]], where he practiced for over 25 years. Wilson was also a municipal judge in [[Springdale, Lexington County, South Carolina|Springdale, South Carolina]].{{cite web|title= Wilson, Addison Graves "Joe" |url= http://www.ourcampaigns.com/CandidateDetail.html?CandidateID=2083 |date= September 10, 2009 |publisher= Our Campaigns |accessdate=September 12, 2009}} Wilson was active in South Carolina Republican politics when the party barely existed in the state. He took part in his first Republican campaign in 1962, when he was 15 years old. He served as an aide to [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Strom Thurmond]] and to his district's Congressman, [[Floyd Spence]]. In 1981 and 1982, during the first term of the [[Reagan Administration]], Wilson served as deputy general counsel for former Governor [[James B. Edwards|Jim Edwards]] at the [[U.S. Department of Energy]]. Wilson is also a graduate of [[Morton Blackwell]]'s [[Leadership Institute]] in Arlington, Virginia.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenation.com/blog/right-goes-viral |title=The Right Goes Viral |publisher=''The Nation'' |date=October 21, 2009 |accessdate=October 7, 2010}} ==South Carolina Senate== Wilson was elected to the [[South Carolina Senate]] in 1984 as a Republican from [[Lexington County, South Carolina|Lexington County]]. He was re-elected four times, the last three times unopposed; Lexington County is one of the most Republican counties in the state. He never missed a regular legislative session in 17 years. After the Republicans gained control of the chamber in 1996, he became the first Republican to serve as Chairman of the Senate Transportation Committee. Wilson was a member of the [[Columbia College (Columbia, South Carolina)|Columbia College]] Board of Visitors and [[Coker College]] Board of Trustees. During his tenure in the South Carolina Senate, Wilson was the primary sponsor of bills which included the following: establishing a National Guard license plate,{{cite web|url=http://www.scstatehouse.gov/sess113_1999-2000/bills/150.htm |title=South Carolina General Assembly Bill S0150 |publisher=Scstatehouse.gov |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} providing paid leave for state employees to perform disaster relief services,{{cite web|url=http://www.scstatehouse.gov/sess113_1999-2000/bills/283.htm |title=South Carolina General Assembly Bill S0283 |publisher=Scstatehouse.gov |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} and requiring men aged 18–26 to register for the [[Selective Service System]] when applying for a driver's license.{{cite web|url=http://www.scstatehouse.gov/sess114_2001-2002/bills/634.htm |title=South Carolina General Assembly Bill S0634 |publisher=Scstatehouse.gov |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} In 2000, Wilson was one of seven senators who voted against removing the [[Confederate battle flag]] from being displayed over the state house.{{cite web | title = Rep. Joe Wilson said "the Confederate heritage is very honorable" during SC flag dispute | work = Facing South | publisher = The Institute for Southern Studies | url = http://www.southernstudies.org/2009/09/rep-joe-wilson-said-the-confederate-heritage-is-very-honorable-in-1999.html | accessdate = September 11, 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090914035345/http://www.southernstudies.org/2009/09/rep-joe-wilson-said-the-confederate-heritage-is-very-honorable-in-1999.html | archivedate = September 14, 2009 | df = mdy-all }} ==U.S. House of Representatives== ===Committee assignments=== [[File:Joe Wilson, official photo portrait, color.jpg|thumb|right|Official House photo portrait, 2006]] [[File:George W. Bush and Joe Wilson.png|thumb|right|Wilson with [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] in 2002]]As of the [[113th United States Congress|113th Congress]], Wilson serves on three [[standing committees]] and various subcommittees overseeing specific areas of legislation. Wilson serves on the [[United States House Committee on Armed Services|Committee on Armed Services]] and is Chairman of the [[United States House Armed Services Subcommittee on Military Personnel|Subcommittee on Military Personnel]];{{cite web |title=Armed Services Committee – Military Personnel |url=http://armedservices.house.gov/index.cfm/military-personnel |work=house.gov |publisher=House Armed Services Committee |date=January 13, 2013 |accessdate=June 5, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130530044723/http://armedservices.house.gov/index.cfm/military-personnel |archivedate=May 30, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} he also serves on the [[United States House Armed Services Subcommittee on Strategic Forces|Subcommittee on Strategic Forces]].{{cite web |title=Armed Services Committee – Strategic Forces |url=http://armedservices.house.gov/index.cfm/strategic-forces |work=house.gov |publisher=House Armed Services Committee |date=January 13, 2013 |accessdate=June 5, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130218141321/http://armedservices.house.gov/index.cfm/strategic-forces |archivedate=February 18, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} He serves on the [[United States House Committee on Education and the Workforce|Committee on Education and the Workforce]], for which he also is a member of the [[United States House Education Subcommittee on Health, Employment, Labor, and Pensions|Subcommittee on Health, Employment, Labor, and Pensions]].{{cite web |title=Members, Subcommittees & Jurisdictions |url=http://edworkforce.house.gov/committee/subcommitteesjurisdictions.htm |work=house.gov |publisher=Education & the Workforce Committee |date= |accessdate=June 5, 2013}} As a member of the [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|Committee on Foreign Affairs]], Wilson serves on the [[United States House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Europe|Subcommittee on Europe]]{{cite web |title=Subcommittee on Europe |url=http://www.internationalrelations.house.gov/subcommittees.asp?committee=4 |work=house.gov |publisher=United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs |date= |accessdate=September 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091104091803/http://internationalrelations.house.gov/subcommittees.asp?committee=4 |archivedate=November 4, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} and [[United States House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on the Middle East and South Asia|Subcommittee on the Middle East and South Asia]].{{cite web |title=Subcommittee on the Middle East and South Asia |url=http://www.internationalrelations.house.gov/subcommittees.asp?committee=7 |work=house.gov |publisher=United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs |date= |accessdate=September 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007052622/http://www.internationalrelations.house.gov/subcommittees.asp?committee=7 |archivedate=October 7, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} Wilson is a member of the [[Republican Study Committee]]{{cite web|title=Member List|author=|url=https://rsc-walker.house.gov/|format=|publisher=Republican Study Committee|date=|accessdate=22 January 2018}} and the [[Tea Party Caucus]]. ===Caucus memberships=== * Composites Caucus (Co-Chair) * Diabetes Caucus * Global Health Caucus * India Caucus *[[United States Congressional International Conservation Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Our Members|author=|url=https://royce.house.gov/internationalconservation/members.html|publisher=U.S. House of Representatives International Conservation Caucus |date=|accessdate=5 August 2018}} * Israel Allies Caucus * Russia Democracy Caucus * Sportsmen's Caucus * [[Steering and Policy Committee of the United States House of Representatives|House Republican Policy Committee]] * [[Tea Party Caucus]] * [[Congressional Arts Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Membership|author=|url=https://artscaucus-slaughter.house.gov/membership|format=|publisher=Congressional Arts Caucus|date=|accessdate=21 March 2018}} * [[Congressional Constitution Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=https://congressionalconstitutioncaucus-garrett.house.gov/about-us/membership|format=|publisher=Congressional Constitution Caucus|date=|accessdate=8 May 2018}} * [[Afterschool Caucuses]]{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=http://www.afterschoolalliance.org/policyCongressionalCaucuses.cfm|format=|publisher=Afterschool Alliance|date=|accessdate=17 April 2018}} * [[Congressional NextGen 9-1-1 Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Members|author=|url=http://www.ng911institute.org/about-the-congressional-nextgen-9-1-1-caucus|format=|publisher=Congressional NextGen 9-1-1 Caucus|date=|accessdate=8 June 2018}} Like his former boss, Spence, Wilson is an ardent social and fiscal conservative, and a strong supporter of the military.{{cite web|url=http://www.votesmart.org/issue_rating_category.php?can_id=BS021931 |title=Project Vote Smart – Representative Addison Graves 'Joe' Wilson Sr. – Interest Group Ratings |publisher=Votesmart.org |date=December 18, 2001 |accessdate=December 8, 2009}} He is a member of the [[Republican Study Committee]]. In 2003, Wilson voted for the [[Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act]], including its Section 1011 authorizing $250,000 annually of taxpayer money to reimburse hospitals for treatment of illegal immigrants. In 2009, Wilson changed to his current position opposing public funds for healthcare of illegal immigrants.{{cite web |last= Shaw |first= Donny |title= Joe Wilson Voted to Provide Taxpayer Money for Illegal Immigrants' Healthcare |url= http://www.opencongress.org/articles/view/1219-Joe-Wilson-Voted-to-Provide-Taxpayer-Money-for-Illegal-Immigrants-Healthcare |date= September 11, 2009 |publisher= OpenCongress.org |accessdate= September 12, 2009 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090912223059/http://www.opencongress.org/articles/view/1219-Joe-Wilson-Voted-to-Provide-Taxpayer-Money-for-Illegal-Immigrants-Healthcare |archivedate= September 12, 2009 |df= mdy-all }} ===Legislation=== Wilson has sponsored and co-sponsored a number of [[bill (proposed law)|bills]], concerning teacher recruitment and retention, college campus fire safety, National Guard troop levels, arming airline pilots, tax credits for adoptions, tax credits for living organ donors, and state defense forces. As of January 2006, eight bills co-sponsored by Wilson have passed the House,{{cite web |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/person.xpd?id=400433 |title=Addison (Joe) Wilson |date= |work=GovTrack.us |publisher= |accessdate=November 2, 2009 }} including H.R. 1973, the [[Senator Paul Simon Water for the Poor Act of 2005]], making safe water and sanitation an objective of U.S. assistance to developing countries.{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:HR01973:@@@P: |title=Thomas (Library of Congress): H.R. 1973 |publisher=Thomas.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} Wilson is a staunch advocate of a federal prohibition of online [[poker]]. In 2006, he co-sponsored H.R. 4411, the [[Goodlatte]]-Leach Internet Gambling Prohibition Act{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:h.r.04411: |title=Thomas (Library of Congress): HR 4411 |publisher=Thomas.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} and H.R. 4777, the Internet Gambling Prohibition Act.{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:h.r.04777: |title=Thomas (Library of Congress): HR 4777 |publisher=Thomas.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} He has cited as one of his proudest congressional achievements the Drafting Business Expensing Act of 2003{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}}, which allows businesses to immediately write-off fifty percent of the cost of business equipment and machinery. This bonus [[depreciation]] provision has been extended for 2008 and 2009 in two separate stimulus bills.{{cite web |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-110publ185/content-detail.html |title=Public Law 110-185 – Economic Stimulus Act of 2008 |date=February 13, 2008 |work= |publisher=gpo.gov |accessdate=November 21, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/assets/documents/Public_Law-111-5.pdf |title=PUBLIC LAW 111–5— |date=February 17, 2009 |work= |publisher=whitehouse.gov |accessdate=November 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091014112424/http://www.whitehouse.gov/%2fassets%2fdocuments%2fPublic_Law-111-5.pdf |archivedate=October 14, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} In addition, Wilson spearheaded the Drafting Teacher Recruitment and Retention Act of 2003, which offers higher education loan forgiveness to math, science and special education teachers in schools with a predominantly low income student population.James Rosen, [http://www.thestate.com/news-extras/story/936307.html "Joe Wilson Biography"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090912085107/http://www.thestate.com/news-extras/story/936307.html |date=September 12, 2009 }}, ''[[The State (newspaper)|The State]]'', September 10, 2009 He cites as his most important vote the [[Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003]]. ==="You lie!" outburst during Obama address=== [[File:Joe Wilson's You Lie interruption.theora.ogv|thumb|Wilson's interruption of President Obama's address (at 00:15)]] On September 9, 2009, Wilson shouted at President [[Barack Obama]] while Obama [[Barack Obama speech to joint session of Congress, September 2009|addressed a joint session of Congress]] to outline his proposal for [[Health care reform in the United States|reforming health care]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/10/you-lie-joe-wilson-obama-speech| author=Batty, David |title='You lie': Republican Joe Wilson's outburst at Obama health speech |date=September 10, 2009 |accessdate=June 3, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}} During his address, Obama said: "There are also those who claim that our reform effort will insure illegal immigrants. This, too, is false – the reforms I'm proposing would not apply to those who are here illegally."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/10/us/politics/10obama.text.html?pagewanted=print |title=Obama's Health Care Speech to Congress |date=September 9, 2009 |publisher=New York Times | accessdate=May 6, 2010}} In a breach of [[decorum]],{{cite news|title=Wilson Apologizes After Accusing Obama of a 'Lie' |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601103&sid=aJTZYsFoY1UQ|agency=Bloomberg |date= September 10, 2009|accessdate=September 10, 2009 |language=|quote=}} Wilson pointed at Obama and shouted, "You lie!" twice.{{cite news|title=Obama heckled by GOP during speech to Congress |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gTWB1M9VPOte4M77spW7Z62NsGyQD9AK4ULO0 |agency=Associated Press |date=September 10, 2009 |accessdate=September 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090916221551/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gTWB1M9VPOte4M77spW7Z62NsGyQD9AK4ULO0 |archivedate=September 16, 2009 }}[http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/0909/A_voice_from_the_floor_on_illegal_immigrants_Lie.html Politico:"A voice from the floor on illegal immigrants: 'Lie'"]. Retrieved September 9, 2009.[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/09/09/gop-rep-wilson-yells-out_n_281480.html "The Huffington Post: "GOP Rep Joe Wilson Yells Out "Lie" During Obama Health Care Speech To Congress (VIDEO)"]. Retrieved September 9, 2009.{{cite news|first=Alex|last=Spillius|title=Barack Obama health care speech: Republican calls president a liar|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/6165489/Barack-Obama-health-care-speech-Republican-calls-president-a-liar.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|publisher=|date=September 10, 2009|accessdate=September 9, 2009 | location=London}} Wilson attracted national and international attention for the incident.''[[Der Spiegel]]'', [http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,648158,00.html Web-Gemeinde schimpft auf Obamas Störenfried] 10.09.2009 (German), ''[[Le Monde]]'' [http://www.lemonde.fr/archives/article/2009/09/10/reforme-de-la-sante-les-etats-unis-decouvrent-le-combattant-obama_1238389_0.html Réforme de la santé : les Etats-Unis découvrent le "combattant" Obama]. 10.09.09 (French – dubs him "Joe 'You Lie' Wilson"), ''[[El País]]'', [http://www.elpais.com/articulo/internacional/Obama/Ha/llegado/momento/aprobar/reforma/sanitaria/elpepuint/20090910elpepuint_2/Tes Obama: "Ha llegado el momento de aprobar la reforma sanitaria"]. 10.09.09 (Spanish).''[[Time (magazine)|Time]], September 10, 2009, [http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,1921455,00.html "'You Lie!': Representative Wilson's Outburst"] He said afterwards that his outburst reflected his view that the bill would provide government-subsidized benefits to illegal immigrants.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,549243,00.html |title=FOX News coverage of Wilson controversy |publisher=Foxnews.com |date=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} Then-White House Chief of Staff [[Rahm Emanuel]] immediately approached senior Republican lawmakers and asked them to identify the heckler and urge him to apologize immediately.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/11/us/politics/11Wilson.html | work=The New York Times | first=Carl | last=Hulse | title=In Lawmaker's Outburst, a Rare Breach of Protocol | date=September 11, 2009}} Members of Congress from both parties condemned the outburst. "Totally disrespectful", said Senator [[John McCain]] (R-[[Arizona]]) of Wilson's utterance. "No place for it in that setting or any other and he should apologize immediately."{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0909/09/lkl.01.html |title=CNN.com – Transcripts |publisher=Transcripts.cnn.com |date=September 9, 2009 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}[http://thedailyvoice.com/voice/2009/09/south-carolina-rep-joe-wilson-002258.php ''The Daily Voice'': "South Carolina Rep. Joe Wilson calls the President a liar during speech"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090913123238/http://thedailyvoice.com/voice/2009/09/south-carolina-rep-joe-wilson-002258.php |date=September 13, 2009 }}. Retrieved September 9, 2009. Wilson said later in a statement:
This evening I let my emotions get the best of me when listening to the President's remarks regarding the coverage of undocumented immigrants in the health care bill. While I disagree with the President's statement, my comments were inappropriate and regrettable. I extend sincere apologies to the President for this lack of civility.[http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/09/09/wilson-apologizes-i-let-my-emotions-get-the-best-of-me/ "Wilson apologizes: 'I let my emotions get the best of me'"]. Retrieved September 9, 2009.
Obama later accepted Wilson's apology. "I'm a big believer that we all make mistakes", he said. "He apologized quickly and without equivocation and I'm appreciative of that."{{cite news|last= Stolberg|first= Sheryl Gay|title= Obama Accepts Wilson's Apology|url= http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/10/obama-accepts-wilsons-apology/?hp|date= September 10, 2009 |work= New York Times|accessdate=September 10, 2009}} {{Wikisource|Raising a Question of the Privileges of the House|Raising a Question of the Privileges of the House (H. Res. 744)}} House Democrats called on Wilson to issue a formal apology on the House floor.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/domesticNews/idUSTRE58C14N20090913 |title=Lawmaker won't apologize to Obama in Congress | U.S. |agency=Reuters |date=February 9, 2009 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} House Majority Whip [[Jim Clyburn]] who led the resolution said "This is about the rules of the House", while House Majority Leader [[Steny Hoyer]] said "What's at issue here is of importance to the House and of importance to the country ... This House cannot stay silent". Wilson refused to make an apology in the House, saying in a televised interview that, "I believe one apology is sufficient."{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_dIpZ8XA64 |title=Joe Wilson: 'One Apology Is Sufficient' |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} Congressional Republicans agreed, and opposed further action, with Minority Leader [[John Boehner]] saying "I think this is a sad day for the House of Representatives ... I think this is a political stunt aimed at distracting the American people from what they really care about, which is health care."{{cite news |first=Mike |last=Soraghan |authorlink= |title=DeMint: No more apologizing for Wilson |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/58423-demint-no-more-apologizing-for-wilson |newspaper=The Hill |publisher= |date=September 12, 2009 |accessdate=September 22, 2009}} On September 15, the House approved a "resolution of disapproval" against Wilson, on 240–179 vote.{{cite news |first=Alex |last=Isenstadt |authorlink= |title=House passes resolution of disapproval |url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0909/27194.html |newspaper=Politico |publisher= |date=September 15, 2009 |accessdate=September 15, 2009}} Several fact-checking organizations wrote that Wilson's views were inaccurate because [[America's Affordable Health Choices Act of 2009|HR 3200]] expressly excludes undocumented aliens from receiving government-subsidized "affordability credits".{{cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2009/09/obamas-health-care-speech/ |title=Obama's Health Care Speech |publisher=FactCheck.org |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}{{cite web|url=http://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2009/sep/09/joe-wilson/joe-wilson-south-carolina-said-obama-lied-he-didnt/ |title=Joe Wilson of South Carolina said Obama lied, but he didn't |publisher=PolitiFact |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/08/27/cnn-truth-squad-will-health-bill-pay-for-illegal-immigrants-an-update/ |title=CNN Political Ticker: All politics, all the time Blog Archive – CNN Truth Squad: Will health bill pay for illegal immigrants? An update " – Blogs from CNN.com |publisher=Politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com |date=August 27, 2009 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}} However, the non-partisan [[Congressional Research Service]] agreed that people would need to be lawfully present in the U.S. in order to be eligible for the credits, but noted that the bill did not bar non-citizens from buying their own health insurance coverage through the [[health insurance exchange]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cis.org/articles/2009/CRS_Report_on_HR3200.pdf |title=Treatment of Noncitizens in H.R. 3200 |date=August 25, 2009 |work=CRS Report for Congress |publisher=Congressional Research Service |accessdate=November 21, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118160833/http://www.cis.org/articles/2009/CRS_Report_on_HR3200.pdf |archivedate=January 18, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web |authorlink= |title=Republicans Cite Report To Support Illegal Alien Health Care Charge |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2009/09/republicans_cite_report_to_sup.html |date=September 10, 2009 |work=[[National Public Radio]] |accessdate=September 10, 2009}} The Obama administration said that, in the final bill, undocumented immigrants would not be able to participate in the Exchange.{{cite news|url=http://prescriptions.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/09/11/illegal-immigrants-could-not-buy-insurance-on-new-exchange-white-house-says/|title=Illegal Immigrants Could Not Buy Insurance on New 'Exchange,' White House Says|date=September 11, 2009|accessdate=September 12, 2009|work=The New York Times|author=Herszenhorn, David M.}} Such language was included in the [[Senate Finance Committee]]'s version of the bill, [[America's Healthy Future Act]].{{cite web|author=HealthiNation |url=http://health.yahoo.com/news/ap/us_health_care_overhaul.html |title=News on Yahoo! Health |publisher=Health.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=August 29, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091223021927/http://health.yahoo.com/news/ap/us_health_care_overhaul.html |archivedate=December 23, 2009 |df= }}{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/09/16/health.care.key.points/ | work=CNN | title=What's in Baucus' health care proposal? | accessdate=May 6, 2010 | date=September 16, 2009}} In contrast to the criticism, many others strongly supported his actions, distrusting that the bill would actually exclude illegal aliens in practice, which allowed Wilson to receive substantial political contributions and gain much notoriety.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/joe-wilsons-you-lie-spurs-support-criticism/ |title=Joe Wilson's "You Lie!" Spurs Support, Criticism |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=2009-09-11 |accessdate=2017-01-16}} Following the incident, both Wilson and Rob Miller, his subsequent 2010 general election opponent, experienced a significant upswing in campaign donations. In the week after Wilson's outburst, Miller raised $1.6 million, about three times his 2008 campaign,{{cite web|url=http://www.opensecrets.org/races/summary.php?id=SC02&cycle=2008|title=Congressional Elections: South Carolina District 02 Race: 2008 Cycle|publisher=OpenSecrets|accessdate=September 16, 2009}} while Wilson raised $1.8 million.{{cite news|first=Holly|last=Bailey|title=How Joe Wilson's Heckle Became a Campaign Cash Cow|url=http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/thegaggle/archive/2009/09/17/how-joe-wilson-s-heckle-became-a-campaign-cash-cow.aspx|newspaper=Newsweek|date=September 17, 2008|accessdate=September 17, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204103320/http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/thegaggle/archive/2009/09/17/how-joe-wilson-s-heckle-became-a-campaign-cash-cow.aspx|archivedate=February 4, 2010}} By September 30, 2009, Wilson had out-paced Miller's fundraising by $2.65 million to $1.69 million respectively. This fundraising surge led to Wilson writing fundraising letters for the [[Republican Party of Virginia]]{{cite web|author=Mark Murray|title=VA GOPers Get Joe Wilson's Help|url=http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/09/23/2078612.aspx|work=First Read|publisher=msnbc.com|date=September 23, 2009|accessdate=September 28, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926152547/http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/09/23/2078612.aspx|archivedate=September 26, 2009|df=mdy-all}} and the [[National Republican Congressional Committee]].{{cite web|author=Mark Murray|title=Joe Wilson, GOP Celebrity?|url=http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/09/25/2080351.aspx|work=First Read|publisher=msnbc.com|date=September 25, 2009|accessdate=September 28, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090928113531/http://firstread.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2009/09/25/2080351.aspx|archivedate=September 28, 2009|df=mdy-all}} Political observers described him as a "GOP fundraising star."{{cite web|author=Alex Koppelman|title=Joe Wilson turns GOP fundraising star|url=http://www.salon.com/politics/war_room/2009/09/25/wilson_email/index.html|work=Salon|date=September 25, 2009|accessdate=September 28, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090927151143/http://www.salon.com/politics/war_room/2009/09/25/wilson_email/index.html|archivedate=September 27, 2009|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=Joe Wilson Becomes GOP Fundraising Star|url=http://www.myfoxdc.com/dpp/news/092509_joe_wilson_becomes_gop_fundraising_star |agency=Associated Press|publisher=myfoxdc.com|date=September 25, 2009|accessdate=October 1, 2009}} ===Other notable moments=== On a 2002 live broadcast of the [[C-SPAN]] talk show ''[[Washington Journal]]'', guests Wilson and Democratic congressman [[Bob Filner]] were discussing [[Iraq]]i [[weapons of mass destruction]]. When Filner noted that the US provided Iraq with "chemical and biological weapons" in the 1980s, Wilson stated that this idea was "made up" and commented to Filner, "This hatred of America by some people is just outrageous. And you need to get over that." Wilson apologized for his remarks in statements to the press."Wilson accuses California congressman of hating America", [[Associated Press]], September 26, 2002[[Lloyd Grove]], "The Reliable Source", ''[[Washington Post]]'', September 25, 2002. In 2003, [[Essie Mae Washington-Williams]] revealed she was the daughter of Wilson's former employer, the late Senator [[Strom Thurmond]], and Thurmond's black maid. Wilson was among those who publicly doubted her assertion that Thurmond had a child [[out of wedlock]]. Wilson said even if her story was true, she should not have revealed it because "it's a [[Smear campaign|smear]]" on Thurmond's image and was a way to "diminish" Thurmond's legacy.Jennifer Talhelm, "Most Say Revelation Won't Alter Thurmond's Legacy", ''[[The State (newspaper)|The State]]'', December 14, 2003 After Thurmond's family acknowledged the truth of Washington-Williams' revelation, Wilson apologized, but said that he still thought that she should not have revealed that Thurmond was her father.Jennifer Talhelm and Aaron Gould Shinin, "Critics of Thurmond's Daughter Change Tune", ''[[The State (newspaper)|The State]]'', December 19, 2003 In November 2009, the ''[[New York Times]]'' reported that Representatives Wilson and [[Blaine Luetkemeyer]] made identical written statements, saying that "One of the reasons I have long supported the U.S. biotechnology industry is that it is a homegrown success story that has been an engine of job creation in this country. Unfortunately, many of the largest companies that would seek to enter the biosimilar market have made their money by outsourcing their research to foreign countries like India." The statement was originally drafted by lobbyists for [[Genentech]], now a Swiss [[biotechnology]] firm, but founded, and still headquartered in [[San Francisco, California]].{{cite news|last1=Pear|first1=Robert|title=In House, Many Spoke With One Voice: Lobbyists'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/15/us/politics/15health.html|accessdate=12 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=15 November 2009|page=A1}} Wilson supported President [[Donald Trump]]'s 2017 [[Executive Order 13769|executive order]] to impose a temporary ban on entry to the U.S. to citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries, saying that the order would "secure our borders and keep American families safe from terrorist attacks."{{cite web|last1=Blake|first1=Aaron|title=Coffman, Gardner join Republicans against President Trump's travel ban; here's where the rest stand|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/01/29/heres-where-republicans-stand-on-president-trumps-controversial-travel-ban|newspaper=Washington Post|date=January 31, 2017}} On April 10, 2017, a Wilson [[town hall meeting]] at [[Aiken Technical College]] in [[Graniteville, South Carolina]] was interrupted by activists chanting "you lie" as the Congressman asserted that the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] was causing people to be denied health services.{{cite news|last1=Bromwich|first1=Jonah Engel|title=Congressman Who Shouted 'You Lie' at Obama Hears the Same From Constituents|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/11/us/politics/joe-wilson-you-lie-obama-town-hall.html|accessdate=12 April 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=12 April 2017|page=A15}} In 2018, a segment with Wilson aired as part of [[Sacha Baron Cohen]]'s Showtime series, ''[[Who is America?]]''. Wilson endorses "Kinderguardians," a phony program to teach and arm schoolchildren as young as 3 to protect themselves in the classroom.{{cite news |last= Stuever |first= Hank|date=July 15, 2018 |title=Sacha Baron Cohen still knows how to punk America, but his new show erodes what little trust we have left |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/sacha-baron-cohen-still-knows-how-to-punk-america-but-his-new-show-erodes-what-little-trust-we-have-left/2018/07/15/2ef45262-8784-11e8-8f6c-46cb43e3f306_story.html?utm_term=.61bca3186d79|work=Washington Post |location=Washington DC |access-date=July 15, 2018 }} Advocating for toddler carry, he states on camera "A 3-year-old cannot defend itself from an assault rifle by throwing a [[Hello Kitty]] pencil case at it".{{cite news |last=Hale |first=Mike |date=July 15, 2018 |title=Review: Sacha Baron Cohen Is Back. Should We Care? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/15/arts/television/who-is-america-review-sacha-baron-cohen.html |work= New York Times|location=New York |access-date= July 15, 2018}} ==Political campaigns== Wilson was elected in 2001 in a special election caused by the death of Floyd Spence, his former boss. Wilson once said that a dying Spence called him from his hospital bed and asked him to run.Philip Rucker and Ann Gerhart, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/10/AR2009091002051_pf.html "The Gentlemen From South Carolina: State Has a History of Rowdy Politics"], ''[[Washington Post]]'', September 11, 2009. In a crowded five-way Republican primary—the real contest in this heavily Republican district—Wilson tallied 75 percent of the vote, more than enough to win the nomination outright. He prevailed in the December 18 special election with 73 percent of the vote.[http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/external/pre-election/state_districts/SC.html?SITE=NCGRDELN&SECTION=POLITICS&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT AP.org]; retrieved April 10, 2008. Wilson won election to a full term in 2002 with 84 percent of the vote, facing four minor-party candidates. He received 144,149 votes to 17,189 and 9,650 minor party candidates with 371 write-in votes.[https://web.archive.org/web/20061031013017/http://www.scvotes.org/statistics/election_returns_from_primaries_and_general_elections_statewide South Carolina Election Commission official web site, go to the page for November 5, 2002 general election]; retrieved April 10, 2008. Wilson was mentioned as a possible candidate for retiring Senator [[Ernest Hollings|Fritz Hollings]]' seat in 2004, but he decided to run for a second full term and beat his opponents, [[United States Democratic Party|Democrat]] Michael Ellisor and [[Constitution Party (United States)|Constitution Party]] nominee Steve Lefemine, with 65 percent of the vote. Wilson got 181,862 votes to 93,249 for Democrat Ellisor, and 4,447 for minor party candidate Lefemine, with 312 write-ins.[https://web.archive.org/web/20061031013017/http://www.scvotes.org/statistics/election_returns_from_primaries_and_general_elections_statewide South Carolina Election Commission official web site, go to the page for November 2, 2004 general election]; retrieved April 10, 2008. ===2006=== In the 2006 elections, he defeated Ellisor again, gaining 62.7 percent of the vote, and kept his House seat.Wilson received 127,811 votes to Ellisor's 76,090 votes, with 151 write-ins. See [https://web.archive.org/web/20061031013017/http://www.scvotes.org/statistics/election_returns_from_primaries_and_general_elections_statewide South Carolina Election Commission official web site, go to the page for November 7, 2006 general election]. Retrieved April 10, 2008. ===2008=== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in South Carolina, 2008#District 2}} Wilson won re-election in November 2008, defeating the Democratic nominee, Iraq War veteran Rob Miller, 54% to 46%.{{cite news |title= U.S. House |newspaper= [[USA Today]] |page= A16|date= November 5, 2008 }} It was the closest race in the district in 20 years, and the closest race that Wilson had ever faced in 24 years as an elected official. He only survived by winning his native Lexington County by 33,000 votes, more than the overall margin of 26,000 votes. ===2010=== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in South Carolina, 2010#District 2}} Challenged by Democratic nominee Rob Miller, Libertarian nominee Eddie McCain, and Constitution Party nominee Marc Beaman,[http://www.scvotes.org/files/2010%20GE%20Candidate%20Names%20by%20Office%20and%20Party%20Report.pdf Official candidate list] SC Secretary of State Wilson won re-election on November 2, 2010, defeating Miller 53% to 44%. ===2012=== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in South Carolina, 2012}} Redistricting made the 2nd somewhat more compact. It lost [[Beaufort, South Carolina|Beaufort]] and [[Hilton Head Island, South Carolina|Hilton Head Island]]. To make up for the loss in population, it absorbed all of Aiken County and a slice of [[Orangeburg County, South Carolina|Orangeburg County]]. In the November 2012 general election, Wilson ran unopposed and was re-elected with 96% of the vote. ===2014=== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in South Carolina, 2014#District 2}} Challenged by Democratic nominee Phil Black, and Labor Party nominee Harold Geddings III,{{cite web|url=http://www.enr-scvotes.org/SC/53424/149816/en/summary.html#|title=South Carolina Election Commission Official Results|publisher=West Virginia Secretary of State|date=November 4, 2014|accessdate=January 8, 2015}} Wilson won re-election on November 4, 2014, defeating Black 62% to 35%. === 2016 === Challenged by Democratic nominee Arik Bjorn, and American Party nominee Eddie McCain,{{Cite news|url=https://ballotpedia.org/South_Carolina's_2nd_Congressional_District_election,_2016|title=South Carolina's 2nd Congressional District election, 2016 - Ballotpedia|work=Ballotpedia|access-date=2018-11-22|language=en-US}} Wilson won re-election on November 8, 2016, defeating Bjorn 62% to 35%. === 2018 === Challenged by Democratic nominee Sean Carrigan and American Party candidate Sonny Narang,{{Cite news|url=https://ballotpedia.org/South_Carolina's_2nd_Congressional_District_election,_2018|title=South Carolina's 2nd Congressional District election, 2018 - Ballotpedia|work=Ballotpedia|access-date=2018-11-22|language=en-US}} Wilson won re-election on November 2, 2016, defeating Carrigan 56.3% to 42.5%. ==Electoral history== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em ; font-size:95%" |+ {{ushr|South Carolina|2|}}: Results 2000–2016{{cite web|url=http://history.house.gov/Institution/Election-Statistics/Election-Statistics|title=Election Statistics|accessdate=June 4, 2013|publisher=Office of the Historian, United States House of Representatives}}{{cite web|url=http://www.enr-scvotes.org/SC/53424/148763/en/summary.html |title=2014 Statewide General Election RSS |website=Enr-scvotes.org |accessdate=2017-01-16}} !|Year ! write-ins received 71 votes. In 2001, write-ins received 1 vote. In 2002, write-ins received 371 votes. * Floyd Spence died in office, causing the 2001 special election to be held. Wilson served the remainder of the term. {{refend}} ==Personal life== {{BLP sources section|date=January 2017}} An [[Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church|Associate Reformed Presbyterian]],[http://www.firstprescola.com/590634 First Presbyterian of Columbia website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701004140/http://www.firstprescola.com/590634 |date=July 1, 2013 }}, firstprescola.com; accessed January 16, 2017. Wilson and his wife, Roxanne Dusenbury McCrory Wilson, have four sons and six grandchildren. All four sons are [[eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scouts]]. * [[Alan McCrory Wilson|Alan]], the eldest son, is Attorney General for the state of South Carolina. He is a lieutenant colonel in the [[United States National Guard|Army National Guard]], having served a year as an intelligence officer in southern Iraq. * Addison G. Wilson Jr. is a graduate of the [[United States Naval Academy|U.S. Naval Academy]] and is a lieutenant commander and graduate of the [[Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences]] medical school. * Julian Dusenbury Wilson is a graduate of [[Clemson University]] and is a captain in the Army National Guard. Julian is also part owner of Palmetto State Armory one of the largest distributors of assault rifles in the United States. * Hunter Taylor Wilson is a graduate of Clemson University, where he was a member of the Army ROTC, Army National Guard and the [[Sigma Chi]] Fraternity. In a 2005 guest article on [[Rediff.com]], Wilson stated that his father, Hugh, was a member of the [[Flying Tigers]] in World War II.{{cite web|last=Wilson|first=Joe|title=Where the world is without fear|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2005/dec/28joe.htm|date=September 28, 2005|publisher=Rediff|accessdate=September 10, 2009}} The Wilson family attends First Presbyterian Church in Columbia. Wilson has been a member and former President or Chairman of the Cayce-West Columbia [[Rotary Club]], Sheriff's Department Law Enforcement Advisory Council, Reserve Officers Association, Lexington County Historical Society, County Community and Resource Development Committee, [[American Heart Association]], Mid-Carolina Mental Health Association, and NationsBank Lexington Advisory Board. Wilson has also been a member of the Columbia [[World Affairs Councils of America|World Affairs Council]], [[Fellowship of Christian Athletes]], [[Woodmen of the World]], [[Sons of Confederate Veterans]], [[American Legislative Exchange Council]], [[Navy League of the United States|Navy League]], [[AMVETS]], [[Association of the US Army]], [[National Guard Association of the United States|National Guard Association]], [[Air Force Association]], [[American Legion]] and [[Boy Scouts of America]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20050225221947/http://joewilson.house.gov/Biography/extensivebio.htm ] ==See also== * [[List of United States Representatives expelled, censured, or reprimanded]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wikisource author}} * [http://joewilson.house.gov/ Congressman Joe Wilson] official U.S. House site * [http://www.joewilsonforcongress.com/ Joe Wilson for U.S. Congress] * {{Dmoz|Regional/North_America/United_States/South_Carolina/Government/Federal/US_House_of_Representatives/Joe_Wilson_%5BR-2%5D|Joe Wilson}} * {{CongLinks | congbio=W000795 | votesmart=3985 | fec=H2SC02059 | congress=joe-wilson/1688 }} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071010201801/http://www.medillnewsdc.com/cgi-bin/ultimatebb.cgi?ubb=next_topic&f=6&t=000127&go=newer "Congressman with military ties backs Iraq war"] Darran Simon, ''Medill News Service'', February 18, 2004 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080207112049/http://www.palmettoscoop.com/2008/02/03/dont-turn-back-the-page-on-border-security/ "Don’t Turn Back the Page on Border Security"] Op-ed by Joe Wilson, ''Palmetto Scoop'', February 3, 2008 {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox |before = [[Floyd Spence]] |state = South Carolina |district = 2 |start = 2001}} |- {{s-prec|usa}} {{s-bef|before=[[Stephen F. Lynch|Stephen Lynch]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Seniority in the United States House of Representatives|United States Representatives by seniority]]|years=94th}} {{s-aft|after=[[Rob Bishop]]}} {{s-end}} {{SC-FedRep}} {{USCongRep-start|congresses= 107th–115th [[United States Congress]]es |state=[[South Carolina]]}} {{USCongRep/SC/107/2}} {{USCongRep/SC/108}} {{USCongRep/SC/109}} {{USCongRep/SC/110}} {{USCongRep/SC/111}} {{USCongRep/SC/112}} {{USCongRep/SC/113}} {{USCongRep/SC/114}} {{USCongRep/SC/115}} {{USCongRep-end}} {{USHouseCurrent}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wilson, Joe}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]] [[Category:American Presbyterians]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Associate Reformed Presbyterian Church]] [[Category:Censured or reprimanded members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Lawyers from Charleston, South Carolina]] [[Category:Leadership Institute alumni and associates]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from South Carolina]] [[Category:Military personnel from South Carolina]] [[Category:National Guard of the United States colonels]] [[Category:People from West Columbia, South Carolina]] [[Category:Politicians from Charleston, South Carolina]] [[Category:Reagan administration personnel]] [[Category:Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:South Carolina lawyers]] [[Category:South Carolina National Guard personnel]] [[Category:South Carolina Republicans]] [[Category:South Carolina state senators]] [[Category:Tea Party movement activists]] [[Category:United States Army officers]] [[Category:United States Army reservists]] [[Category:University of South Carolina alumni]] [[Category:Washington and Lee University alumni]]

revision.text:
[[File:Toussaint L'Ouverture.jpg|thumb|[[Toussaint L'Ouverture]] (1802). According to biographer Philippe Girard, there is no known portrait of Joseph Bunel.Girard, "Trading Races."]] '''Joseph R. E. Bunel''' was a representative of the Haitian Revolutionary Government, who negotiated the first trade agreement between his nation and the United States, in 1799. ==Biography== Born in France, he became a merchant and plantation manager in Cap-Français, Saint-Domingue (now [[Cap-Haïtien, Haiti]]). Although white and a slave-holder, his wife, Marie Fanchette Estève, was a free-black [[Creole peoples#Caribbean|Creole]], and he was sympathetic to the 1791 [[Haitian Revolution]] through which the former-colony won its independence from France. He served as a diplomatic and trade envoy for Governor [[Toussaint Louverture]], a self-educated former slave. He did the same for Louverture's successor, [[Jean-Jacques Dessalines]].Girard, "Trading Races." He played an important administrative role in Louverture's regime, drafting trade and non-aggression agreements between Saint-Domingue and the United States and Great Britain. Louverture trusted Bunel enough to make him the country's Paymaster General. ===United States=== In July 1798, the United States rescinded its treaties with France, beginning two years of low-level conflict known as the [[Quasi-War]]. L'Ouverture saw this breach as an opportunity. In early-December 1798, Bunel came to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, then the capital of the United States, to try to end the American trade embargo against Saint-Domingue. He met and dined with Secretary of State [[Timothy Pickering]], and was invited to meet President [[John Adams]].Alexander DeConde, ''The Quasi-War'' (New York: Scribner's, 1966), pp. 135-36. In early-January 1799, he dined with Adams.Brown, "Toussaint's Clause," p. 137. Debate in Congress over "Toussaint's Clause" focused on the consequences of legitimizing a revolutionary government run by former-slaves, and how American slave-holders would be endangered by interaction between their slaves and Saint-Dominguans. Pennsylvania Congressman [[Albert Gallatin]] appealed to racial prejudice in his notorious "Black Speech" (January 21, 1799), using Bunel (who had brought his wife with him) as an example of [[miscegenation]] taking place in Philadelphia:
"The General [L'Ouverture] is black, and his agent here is married to a black woman in this city."Thomas Hart Benton, ''Abridgment of the Debates of Congress, from 1789 to 1856 Vol. 2'' (New York: D. Appleton and Company, 1857), p. 339.[https://books.google.com/books?id=eMY4AAAAIAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=thomas+hart+benton+Abridgement+of+the+debates&source=bl&ots=Im9gQznF80&sig=hcUlUYirVYEky4mTgxLrPgdWjro&hl=en&ei=jlycTP7-LIL7lwe8y4GICg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false]
Congress passed "Toussaint's Clause," and the Bunels returned to Saint-Domingue in mid-February. The United States did not officially recognize the Haitian Revolutionary Government, but the trade agreement was announced by a June 26, 1799 presidential proclamation: [http://thelouvertureproject.org/index.php?title=Proclamation_Regarding_Commerce_with_St._Domingo U.S. Proclamation Regarding Commerce with St. Domingo (1799)]. Following Jefferson's 1800 election as president, American support for Saint-Domingue diminished. ===French invasion=== Article 3 of L'Ouverture's [http://thelouvertureproject.org/index.php?title=Constitution_of_1801_(English) 1801 Haitian Constitution] stated: "''Slaves cannot exist on this territory; servitude is abolished forever. All men are born, live and die free and French.''" But, as the threat from [[Napoleon Bonaparte]] loomed, this provision seems to have been ignored:
"Like the early rulers of Haiti who followed him, Toussaint was willing to participate in a one-way version of the slave trade in order to increase his workforce and his army. Bunel was dispatched to Jamaica to purchase ten thousand slaves from the English ... By the terms of Article 3, such arrivals would have to be freed as soon as they reached the colony, but the cloudy language about 'engagements' suggests that some form of indentured servitude was being contemplated."Madison Smartt Bell, ''Toussaint Louverture'' (Vintage Books, 2008), pp. 210-11.[https://books.google.com/books?id=bkTfVUdVaHYC&pg=PA170&lpg=PA170&dq=joseph+bunel&source=bl&ots=DCyfRZhLc2&sig=ZSeJSOp__Ls903IH_oht5e3ljlw&hl=en&ei=H9OYTLGfMcaAlAfe0oQk&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CBUQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=joseph%20bunel&f=false]
Bonaparte's brother-in-law, General [[Charles Leclerc]], invaded Saint-Domingue in 1802. Bunel's wife was imprisoned, and he was forced to pay what was essentially a ransom."Leclerc jailed the black wife of Louverture's white paymaster and diplomat Joseph Bunel, for example, to force her husband to pay an indemnity." Philippe Girard, "Rebelles with a Cause: Women in the Haitian War of Independence, 1802–04", in ''Gender and History'', 21:1 (April 2009), pp. 60-85.[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-0424.2009.01535.x/full] Leclerc captured and imprisoned L'Ouverture, and deported him to France, where he died in 1803. Bunel was also deported to France. Bunel returned to [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] in 1803, where he became a major exporter of [[contraband]] goods to Saint-Domingue. He returned to Haiti during the reign of Dessalines. He, and later his wife, eventually settled permanently in Haiti.Girard, "Trading Races." ==See also== * [[President's House (Philadelphia, Pennsylvania)]] — Third Presidential Mansion. ==References== * Philippe R. Girard, ''A History of Haiti: Rise and Demise of the Pearl of the Caribbean'' (New York: Palgrave, 2010). * Philippe R. Girard, "Trading Races: Joseph and Marie Bunel, a Diplomat and a Merchant in Revolutionary Saint-Domingue and Philadelphia", ''Journal of the Early Republic'' 30:3 (Fall 2010), pp. 351–76.[http://muse.jhu.edu/login?uri=/journals/journal_of_the_early_republic/v030/30.3.girard.html] * Philippe R. Girard, “Black Talleyrand: Toussaint Louverture’s Secret Diplomacy with England and the United States,” ''William and Mary Quarterly'' 66:1 (Jan. 2009), 87-124. *Gordon S. Brown, ''Toussaint's Clause: The Founding Fathers and the Haitian Revolution'' (University Press of Mississippi, 2005).[https://books.google.com/books?id=kbI01p9l3U8C&pg=PA137&lpg=PA137&dq=%22joseph+bunel%22&source=bl&ots=xI35SAcztq&sig=E6PI81yMq16hk6rpWJZGzXwf1JA&hl=en&ei=-QOYTPn5JMH6lweJtMnRBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CC8Q6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22joseph%20bunel%22&f=false] ===Notes=== {{reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bunel, Joseph}} [[Category:People of the Haitian Revolution]] [[Category:18th-century Haitian people]] [[Category:19th-century Haitian people]] [[Category:People of Saint-Domingue]] [[Category:Haitian people of French descent]]

revision.text:
{{About|Australian singer|American journalist and film critic|Judy Stone (journalist){{!}}Judy Stone}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Judy Stone | image = | image_size = | landscape = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank --> | alt = | caption = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Judith Anne Stone | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1942|1|1|df=y}} | birth_place = | origin = [[Granville, New South Wales]], Australia | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} (death date 1st) --> | death_place = | genre = Pop, country | occupation = Musician | instrument = Vocals, guitar | years_active = 1956–present | label = [[Festival Records|Festival]] | associated_acts = [[Col Joye|Col Joye and the Joy Boys]] | website = <!-- {{URL|www.examplewebsite.com}} {{URL|www.examplewebsite.com|ExampleWebsite.com}} or if URL on Wikidata: {{Official website}} --> }} <!-- only free-content images are allowed for depicting living people. Non-free and "fair use" images, e.g. promo photos, CD/DVD covers, posters, screen captures, etc., will be deleted - see [[WP:NONFREE]] -->
'''Judith Anne Stone''' [[Order of Australia|AM]] (born 1 January 1942) is an Australian pop and country music singer. For much of the 1960s she was a regular performer on ''[[Bandstand (Australia)|Bandstand]]'', a pop music TV show, hosted by [[Brian Henderson (television presenter)|Brian Henderson]]. Stone's top 20 singles on the national charts are "I'll Step Down" (No. 19, February 1962), "4,003,221 Tears from Now" (April 1964), "Born a Woman" (No. 3, September 1966) and "[[Would You Lay with Me (In a Field of Stone) (song)|Would You Lay with Me]]" (No. 2, June 1974). On the Queen's Birthday Honours List of June 2006, Stone was awarded a Member of the Order of Australia, with the citation, "For service to the community as an entertainer at fundraising events for a range of charitable organisations, and as a singer."<ref name="Order of Aus">{{cite web | url = https://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1132980&search_type=simple&showInd=true | title = Honours - Search Australian Honours: Stone, Judith Anne | publisher = It's an Honour | accessdate = 25 July 2016 }}</ref>
==Early life== Stone grew up in the Sydney suburb of [[Granville, New South Wales|Granville]].<ref name="Order of Aus"/><ref name="Spicks Specks">{{cite web | url = http://www.abc.net.au/tv/spicksandspecks/txt/s2362154.htm | title = Episode Thirty Four (17/09/2008) | work = [[Spicks and Specks (TV series)|Spicks and Specks]] | date = 17 September 2008 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 }}</ref><ref name="1961 Bio">{{cite news | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47491996 | title = Ca-rolling Stone gathers fans! | newspaper = [[The Australian Women's Weekly]] | volume = 28 | issue = 52 | date = 31 May 1961 | accessdate = 25 July 2016 | page = 11 (Teenagers' Weekly) | via = [[National Library of Australia]] }} Note: a [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/47491996/4912458 photo] of Stone appears in the article.</ref> She has two younger sisters, Joyce and Janice.<ref name="Bio 2">{{cite news | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article131332638 | title = Pretty 'Mighty atom' strikes the double | newspaper = [[The Cumberland Argus and Fruitgrowers' Advocate|The Cumberland Argus]] | date = 9 August 1961 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 | page = 11 | via = National Library of Australia }} Note: Describes Stone as a 17-year-old: implying she was born in 1944.</ref> From a young age she sang country music at home and her parents bought her a guitar, which she learned to play.<ref name="1961 Bio"/>
== Career == In her early teens Stone entered and won a local talent contest and was noticed by an attendee, [[Reg Lindsay]]. By November 1956 she had joined his touring performance troupe, the Reg Lindsay Show, and stayed for 18 months.<ref name="1961 Bio"/><ref name="Reg Show 1">{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article131386466 |title=Advertising: The Reg Lindsay Show |newspaper=[[The Cumberland Argus]] |issue=3358 |date=14 November 1956 |accessdate=26 July 2016 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In July 1957 a reviewer of Lindsay's show in [[Cabramatta, New South Wales|Cabramatta]] for ''[[The Biz (newspaper)|The Biz]]'' wrote that "Little Judy Stone, of Granville, was very pleasing in her turn."<ref name="Reg Show 2">{{cite news | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article189947450 | title = Reg Lindsay at Cabramatta | newspaper = [[The Biz (newspaper)|The Biz]] | date = 10 July 1957 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 | page = 6 | via = National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Stone hired [[Kevin Jacobsen]] as her talent agent.<ref name="1961 Bio"/><ref name="Bio 2"/> She described meeting him, "I used to sing, with a heavy guitar, Western style numbers. Once I met Kevin he gave me one instruction: 'Throw that guitar out the window.' Although I did not throw it out any window, I am now singing without any of my own musical accompaniment."<ref name="Bio 2"/> Jacobsen's older brother, [[Col Joye]], was an established pop singer and regular performer on ''[[Bandstand (Australia)|Bandstand]]'', a TV music show.<ref name="1961 Bio"/><ref name="Bio 2"/> Stone supported his group, Joye and the Joy Boys, on their tours of South Australia, Victoria and Queensland.<ref name="1961 Bio"/> Stone, as a young performer, had been billed as "The Cowgirl from Granville" but on her first appearance on ''Bandstand'' she was mistakenly announced as "The [[Callgirl]] from Granville".<ref name="Spicks Specks"/> By May 1961 she had also appeared on other TV music shows, ''Teen Time'' and ''[[Six O'Clock Rock]]''.<ref name="1961 Bio"/>
Jacobsen had Stone signed with [[Festival Records]] and in June 1961 she issued her debut single, "You're Driving Me Mad" – a cover version of the 1958 song by United States singer, [[Jo Ann Campbell]].<ref name="McFarlane">{{cite book | last1 = McFarlane | first1 = Ian | authorlink1 = Ian McFarlane | title = [[Encyclopedia of Australian Rock and Pop]] | chapter = Encyclopedia entry for 'Judy Stone' | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040823035443/http://www.whammo.com.au/encyclopedia.asp?articleid=417 | chapterurl = http://www.whammo.com.au/encyclopedia.asp?articleid=417 | year = 1999 | publisher = [[Allen & Unwin]] | location = [[St Leonards, New South Wales|St Leonards, NSW]] | archivedate = 23 August 2004 | isbn = 1-86508-072-1 }}</ref><ref name="Nuttall 1">{{cite web | archiveurl = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/43557/20160504-1246/www.poparchives.com.au/2480/judy-stone/youre-driving-me-mad.html | url = http://www.poparchives.com.au/2480/judy-stone/youre-driving-me-mad.html | title = 'You're Driving Me Mad' – Judy Stone (1961) | work = Pop Archives – Sources of Australian Pop Records from the 50s, 60s and 70s | publisher = Lyn Nuttall | archivedate = 4 May 2016 | accessdate = 25 July 2016 }}</ref> For the track she was backed by the Joy Boys.<ref name="Kimball Fest">{{cite web | archiveurl = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/35967/20090315-0738/www.milesago.com/industry/festival-2.html | url = http://www.milesago.com/industry/festival-2.html | title = Industry – Record Labels – Festival Records | last = Kimball | first = Duncan | publisher = Milesago: Australasian Music and Popular Culture 1964–1975. Ice Productions | archivedate = 15 March 2009 | year = 2002 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 }}</ref> In August she relocated to Melbourne, for three months, to appear on Graham Kennedy's ''[[In Melbourne Tonight]]'' variety TV show.<ref name="Bio 2"/> She expected that "While in Melbourne most of my shows will be adult performances, which will be a change from the present teenagers' shows."<ref name="Bio 2"/> Her third single, "I'll Step Down", was released in February 1962 and became a top 10 hit in Sydney and top 20 in Brisbane.<ref name="McFarlane"/><ref name="Nuttall 1"/> ''The Biz''{{'}} correspondent compared it to her earlier single, "Although very different to 'You're Driving Me Mad', this still possesses the inimitable style of this great little local star."<ref name="Step Review">{{cite news | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article189947618 | title = Turntable Talk | newspaper = The Biz | issue = 2910 | date = 28 March 1962 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 | page = 9 | via = National Library of Australia }}</ref> Also in that year Stone issued her debut album, ''I'll Step Down'', on Festival.<ref name="McFarlane"/>
In 1963 she recorded "It Takes a Lot (To Make Me Cry)" on which the [[Bee Gees]] ([[Barry Gibb|Barry]], [[Robin Gibb|Robin]] and [[Maurice Gibb]]) sing backup vocals; it was released as a single in July.<ref name="McFarlane"/><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.columbia.edu/~brennan/beegees/63.html | title = Gibb Songs: 1963 | author = Brennan, Joseph }}</ref> Her seventh single, "4,003,221 Tears from Now", was released in April 1964.<ref name="McFarlane"/> It is a cover version of the 1963 single by US singer Kerri Downs (aka Mary Lou Kiernan).<ref name="Nuttall 2">{{cite web | archiveurl = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/43557/20160504-1246/www.poparchives.com.au/245/judy-stone/4003221-tears-from-now.html | url = http://www.poparchives.com.au/245/judy-stone/4003221-tears-from-now.html | title = '4,003,221 Tears from Now' – Judy Stone (1964) | work = Pop Archives – Sources of Australian Pop Records from the 50s, 60s and 70s | publisher = Lyn Nuttall | archivedate = 4 May 2016 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 }}</ref> According to Australian musicologist, [[Ian McFarlane]], it "became Stone's most popular release of the 1960s. The heart-wrenching ballad... [which] peaked at #8 in Sydney and #7 in Melbourne."<ref name="McFarlane"/>
Aside from her solo releases, Stone was often teamed with Col Joye in duets for singles, extended plays and albums.<ref name="McFarlane"/> McFarlane found their work "contained cutesy material like 'Young and Healthy', 'Angry' and 'Side by Side'."<ref name="McFarlane"/> In early 1965 Stone with Col Joye and the Joy Boys undertook a tour of Japan for two months.<ref name="McFarlane"/> In September 1966 she covered "[[Sandy Posey#.22Born a Woman.22|Born a Woman]]" by US singer, Sandy Posey.<ref name="McFarlane"/><ref name="Nuttall 3">{{cite web | archiveurl = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/43557/20160504-1246/www.poparchives.com.au/161/judy-stone/born-a-woman.html | url = http://www.poparchives.com.au/161/judy-stone/born-a-woman.html | title = 'Born a Woman' – Judy Stone (1966) | work = Pop Archives – Sources of Australian Pop Records from the 50s, 60s and 70s | publisher = Lyn Nuttall | archivedate = 4 May 2016 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 }}</ref> It was a top 10 hit in Sydney.<ref name="McFarlane"/>
From the late 1960s and into the early 1970s Stone "consolidated on her early pop successes with regular appearances on the club and country music circuits."<ref name="McFarlane"/> Later singles included, "Mare Mare Mare" (January 1974), "[[Would You Lay with Me (In a Field of Stone) (song)|Would You Lay with Me (In a Field of Stone)]]" (No. 2, June 1974),<ref name="Kent"/> "Silver Wings and Golden Rings" (February 1975) and "[[Hasta Mañana]]" (May 1976).<ref name="McFarlane"/>
In January 1992 Stone was diagnosed with [[Head and neck cancer|throat cancer]], which was removed by surgery.<ref name="Cancer diag"/>
In 2007 Stone performed a duet with Scottish singer-songwriter Isla Grant on the track "What's a Girl to Do?" for Grant's album, ''Down Memory Lane''.
== Personal life ==
On 25 February 1966, Stone married fellow musician, [[Leo de Kroo]].<ref name="Wedding">{{cite news | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article105888862 | title = Pop Stars Wed | newspaper = [[The Canberra Times]] | volume = 40 | issue = 11,402 | date = 26 February 1966 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 | page = 3 | via = National Library of Australia }}</ref> The de Kroo brothers, Leo and Doug, were a duo who also appeared on ''Bandstand'' and other pop music shows.<ref name="Manning"/><ref name="Ward">{{cite news | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47249042 | title = Three boys take to the sawdust trail | last = Ward | first = Kirsten | newspaper = The Australian Women's Weekly | volume = 29 | issue = 16 | date = 20 September 1961 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 | page = 11 (''Teenagers' Weekly'') | via = National Library of Australia }}</ref> The marriage ended in divorce five years later, Stone reflected, "I blamed myself when it ended, then I realized something its taken a long time to learn – singing is my life... I don't have a social life – there simply isn't time – but I don't get lonely; I have my family."<ref name="Manning">{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article51268476 |title = Judy Stone's new single: 'The year's best kept secret' | last = Manning | first = Fiona | newspaper = The Australian Women's Weekly | volume = 48 | issue = 16 | date = 17 September 1980 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 | page = 32 (Free: ''Your TV Magazine'') | via = National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In January 1992 Stone was diagnosed with [[Head and neck cancer|throat cancer]], at the same time as her fellow ''Bandstand'' regular, [[Peter Allen (musician)|Peter Allen]].<ref name="Cancer diag">{{cite news | url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article126929837 | title = Entertainers mourn singer | newspaper = The Canberra Times | volume = 66 | issue = 20,887 | date = 20 June 1992 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 | page = 17 | via = National Library of Australia}}</ref> Both Stone and Allen were operated on the same day by the same surgeon.<ref name="Cancer diag"/> In June Stone was still in recovery when she learned of Allen's death, she recalled that after the operation "He came into my room to see me because he was going back to the States and I just wanted to give him a big hug — he looked so ill."<ref name="Cancer diag"/>
On the Queen's Birthday Honours List of June 2006, Stone was awarded a [[Order of Australia|Member of the Order of Australia]], with the citation, "For service to the community as an entertainer at fundraising events for a range of charitable organisations, and as a singer."<ref name="Order of Aus">{{cite web | url = https://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/honours/honour_roll/search.cfm?aus_award_id=1132980&search_type=simple&showInd=true | title = Honours - Search Australian Honours: Stone, Judith Anne | publisher = It's an Honour | accessdate = 25 July 2016 }}</ref> In January 2014 she was made [[Australia Day]] Ambassador for regional celebrations in Laurieton, Wauchope and Port Macquarie.<ref name="Oz Day 2014">{{cite web | url = http://www.wauchopegazette.com.au/story/1998715/judy-stone-is-our-ambassador/ | title = Judy Stone is our ambassador | work = Wauchope Gazette | publisher = [[Fairfax Media]] | date = 2 January 2014 | accessdate = 26 July 2016 }}</ref>
==Discography==
=== Albums ===
* ''I'll Step Down'' – (1962) [[Festival Records]] * ''Col and Judy'' <small>(by [[Col Joye]] and Judy Stone)</small> – (1962) Festival Records * ''The Best of Col and Judy'' <small>(by Col Joye and Judy Stone)</small> – (1963) Festival Records * ''Got You on My Mind'' – (1964) Festival Records * ''Pure Stone'' – (1972) Frog Records * ''Born to Lose'' – (1972) Summit Records * ''The Magic of Judy Stone'' – (1973) Summit Records * ''Judy Stone's Greatest Hits'' – (1974) Festival Records * ''In a Field of Stone'' – (1974) M7 Records * ''Judy Stone's Favourites'' – (1975) M7 Records * ''A Part of Me'' – (1976) Polydor Records * ''What are You Doing Tonight?'' – (1978) Polydor Records * ''20 Golden Greats'' – (1983) Festival Records * ''All the Best'' – (1984) Telmak Records
=== Extended plays ===
* ''I Cried'' – (June 1964) [[Festival Records]]
=== Singles ===

[[File:Jüri_Kork_12.4.2012.JPG|thumb|Jüri Kork in 2012]] '''Jüri Kork''' (born 3 August 1947, [[Tartu]]) is an Estonian politician, most notable for voting for the [[Estonian restoration of Independence]].
Kork graduated from Tsirguliin High School in 1966 and the Department of Physical Education from the [[University of Tartu]] in 1970.
He worked as a teacher at [[Põltsamaa]] High School from 1972 to 1976. From 1976 to 1982, he was the chairman of the Sports Committee of the [[Jõgeva County|Jõgeva]] Raion and, from 1982 to 1990, was the director of [[Pühajärve]] Holiday Village.
From [[Estonian Supreme Soviet election, 1990|1990]] to 1992, Kork was a member of the Supreme Soviet of Estonia and the [[Congress of Estonia]], voting for Estonia's restoration of independence. In the Soviet, he was a member of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Family and Social Affairs Committee and later the Administrative Reform Commission. He is a member of the Group of Farmers' Deputies. Kork participated in the founding of the [[Popular Front of Estonia]] in [[Otepää]] and [[Valga County]].<ref>Kes on kes Eesti poliitikas 1988–1992. Eesti Entsüklopeediakirjastus. Tallinn 1992</ref> During the occupation of Estonia by the [[Soviet Union]], he was one of the keepers of the secret of the first [[Estonian flag]]'s hiding place.
== Awards == * 2002: [[Order of the National Coat of Arms|5th Class of the Estonian Order of the National Coat of Arms]] (received 23 February 2002)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.president.ee/en/estonia/decorations/bearer/1076/juri-kork|title=Bearer of decorations: Jüri Kork (V)|access-date=9 July 2018|date=|publisher=Estonian State Decorations}}</ref> * 2006: [[Order of the National Coat of Arms|3rd Class of the Estonian Order of the National Coat of Arms]] (received 23 February 2006)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.president.ee/en/estonia/decorations/bearer/1171/juri-kork|title=Bearer of decorations: Jüri Kork (III)|access-date=9 July 2018|date=|publisher=Estonian State Decorations}}</ref>
== Personal life == Kork's siblings are doctor and politician {{ill|Andres Kork|et}}, politician and businessman [[Toomas Kork]], and nurse and psychiatrist {{ill|Anu Kasmel|et}}.
== References == {{reflist}}
