revision.text:
Below is a list of recipients of the [[Congressional Gold Medal]], the highest civilian honor bestowed by the [[United States Congress]]. == Recipients of Continental Congress Gold Medals == {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%; text-align:left" |- ! !! Recipient(s) !! Date of approval !! Public law !! Notes !! Medal |- | [[Image:Gilbert Stuart Williamstown Portrait of George Washington.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[George Washington]] || March 25, 1776 || [[Continental Congress]] || In honor of the liberation of Boston, first major city liberated from British occupation. Later led the [[Continental Army]] to victory in the [[American Revolutionary War]] (1775–1783). Presented to Washington March 21, 1790 and currently resides at the Boston Public Library.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bpl.org/exhibitions/past-exhibitions/we-are-one/view-the-exhibition-3/we-are-one-54/ |title=We Are One: Mapping America's Road from Revolution to Independence|publisher=Boston Public Library |accessdate=September 13, 2015}}

''Also See'' [[Washington Before Boston Medal]] || [[Image:1776 Washington Before Boston Comitia Americana Second Restrike (Baker-48G) (obv).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:HoratioGates.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Major General]] [[Horatio Gates]] || November 4, 1777 || Continental Congress || Victor in [[Saratoga campaign]]. The medal is currently possessed by the [http://www.nyhistory.org/exhibit/horatio-gates-military-medal New York Historical Society]. ||[[File:Horatio Gates Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Anthony Wayne.jpg|center|75px|border]]|| Major General [[Anthony Wayne]] || July 26, 1779 || Continental Congress || Commander at the [[Battle of Stony Point]]. The medal is currently possessed by the [http://www.amrev.org/resources-programs-and-collections/collections-of-the-society/ Pennsylvania Society of Sons of the Revolution]. ||[[File:Anthony Wayne Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:HenryLee.jpeg|center|75px|border]] || [[Major]] [[Henry Lee III|Henry "Light Horse Harry" Lee]] || September 24, 1779 || Continental Congress ||Commander at the [[Battle of Paulus Hook]]. Only non-general to receive a gold medal during the American Revolutionary War ||[[File:Henry Lee Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:DanielMorgan.jpeg|center|75px|border]] || [[Brigadier General]] [[Daniel Morgan]] || March 9, 1781 || Continental Congress ||Commander at the [[Battle of Cowpens]]. In 1836 Congress (5 Stat. 66) authorized a duplicate be struck to replace the lost original, and be presented to Morgan Neville, his lineal heir||[[File:Daniel Morgan Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Greene portrait.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Major General [[Nathanael Greene]] || October 29, 1781 || Continental Congress ||Commander at the [[Battle of Eutaw Springs]] ||[[File:Nathanael Greene Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Cpt John Paul Jones.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] [[John Paul Jones]] || October 16, 1787 || Continental Congress ||"For his 'valor and brilliant services' during the [[Battle of Flamborough Head]] eight years earlier. Jones became the first and only Continental Navy officer to receive this distinction for his service during the American Revolution."{{Cite web|url=http://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/15032392026?ret=True|title=A Congressional Gold Medal to Captain John Paul Jones |publisher=history.house.gov |accessdate=September 14, 2015}} ||[[File:John Paul Jones Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |} == Recipients of U.S. Congress Gold Medals == {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%; text-align:left" |- ! !! Recipient(s) !! Date of approval !! Public law !! Notes !! Medal |- | [[Image:Thomas Truxtun.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Captain (U.S. Navy)|Captain]] [[Thomas Truxtun]] || March 29, 1800 || 2 Stat. 87{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llac&fileName=010/llac010.db&recNum=312|title=A Century of Lawmaking for a New Nation: U.S. Congressional Documents and Debates, 1774 - 1875|author=|date=|website=memory.loc.gov|accessdate=25 April 2018}}|| Commander of the {{USS|Constellation|1797|6}} during the [[USS Constellation vs La Vengeance|battle against the French frigate ''La Vengeance'']] ||[[File:Thomas Truxtun Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Edward Preble.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]] [[Edward Preble]] || March 3, 1805 || 2 Stat. 346–347 || For 1804 attacks on Tripoli during the [[First Barbary War]] || |- | [[File:1814 IsaacHull Polyanthos.png|center|75px]]
[[File:KN-2779.jpg|center|75px]]
[[File:Jacob Jones.jpg|center|75px]] || Captain [[Isaac Hull]]
Captain [[Stephen Decatur]]
Captain [[Jacob Jones]] || January 29, 1813 || 2 Stat. 830 || For action against the [[HMS Guerriere (1806)|''Guerriere'']], [[HMS Macedonian|''Macedonian'']], and [[HMS Frolic (1806)|''Frolic'']] during the [[War of 1812]]. Silver duplicates awarded to their commissioned officers on board. ||[[File:Isaac Hull Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]]

Gaines]] || November 3, 1814 || 3 Stat. 247 ||For his actions on 15 August 1814 at the Battle of Erie (now known as the [[Siege of Fort Erie]]) || |- | [[Image:AlexanderMacomb.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Major General [[Alexander Macomb (American general)|Alexander Macomb]] || November 3, 1814 || 3 Stat. 247 ||For his actions on 11 September 1814 at The Battle of Plattsburgh || [[Image:Macomb Congressional Medal Obverse.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Andrew Jackson.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Major General [[Andrew Jackson]] || February 27, 1815 || 3 Stat. 249 ||For the [[Battle of New Orleans|defense of New Orleans]] in the [[War of 1812]] || |- | [[File:Commodore Charles Stewart 1841.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Captain [[Charles Stewart (1778-1869)|Charles Stewart]] || February 22, 1816 || 3 Stat. 341 ||For the capture of [[HMS Cyane (1806)|HMS ''Cyane'']] and [[HMS Levant (1813)|HMS ''Levant'']]. Silver medals awarded to his commissioned officers on board. || |- | [[Image:JamesBiddle.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Captain [[James Biddle (commodore)|James Biddle]] || February 22, 1816 || 3 Stat. 341 ||For the capture of [[HMS Penguin (1813)|HMS ''Penguin'']]. March 2, 1847
May 9, 1848 || 9 Stat. 111
9 Stat. 206
9 Stat. 334-335 || For distinguished achievements during military operations along the [[Rio Grande]]
For meritorious achievements at the [[Battle of Monterrey]]
For valor at the [[Battle of Buena Vista]]
Only individual to be awarded three times, all for his [[Mexican–American War]] accomplishments{{cite web| url=http://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/36554?ret=True |title=Future President Zachary Taylor's unprecedented three Congressional Gold Medals |publisher=artandhistory.house.gov |accessdate=2014-03-14}}|| |- | [[Image:USS Somers (1842).jpg|center|75px|border]] || Rescuers of the Officers and Crew of the [[USS Somers (1842)|U.S. Brig ''Somers'']] || March 3, 1847 || 9 Stat. 208 ||Awarded to officers and men of French, British, and Spanish ships who rescued officers and men of the ''Somers'' during the Mexican–American War. || |- | [[Image:Duncan Ingraham.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Commander [[Duncan Ingraham]] || August 4, 1854 || 10 Stat. 594–595 ||For his role in the [[Koszta Affair]] || |- | || [[Frederick Rose (surgeon)]] || May 11, 1858 || 11 Stat. 369 ||First time a Congressional Gold Medal was given to any non-member of the US military.{{Cite web |url= http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/R?r109:FLD001:H00204 |title=Congressional Record - 109th Congress (2005-2006)|work=Library of Congress |accessdate=3 August 2010 }} || |- | [[Image:Ulysses S. The medal is currently possessed by the Smithsonian. ||[[File:U.S. Grant Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Cornelius Vanderbilt Daguerrotype2.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Cornelius Vanderbilt]] || January 28, 1864 || 13 Stat. 401 ||For donating his steamship ''Vanderbilt'' to the [[Union (American Civil War)|Union]] ||[[File:Cornelius Vanderbilt Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | || Captain Robert Creighton

Stouffer || July 26, 1866 || 14 Stat. 365–366 || For rescuing "about 500" Americans from the wreck of the steamship ''San Francisco'' ||[[File:SS San Francisco Congressional Medal Obverse.JPG|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:CyrusField.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Cyrus West Field]] || March 2, 1867 || 14 Stat. 574 ||For establishing the first [[Transatlantic telegraph cable]] || |- | [[Image:Peabodyg.png|center|75px|border]] || [[George Peabody]] || March 16, 1867 || 15 Stat. 20 ||For giving $2,000,000 for the promotion of education in the more destitute portions of the southern and southwestern States. || |- | [[File:George F. Robinson, US Army.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[George F. Robinson]] || March 1, 1871 || 16 Stat. 704 || For actions to protect [[William H. Seward]] during an assassination attempt and save his life afterwards. || |- | || Captain [[Watch Hill Light|Jared Crandall]] and Others || February 24, 1873 || 17 Stat. 638 ||For rescue operations involving the steamer ''Metis''. Statute does not specifically call for gold medals to the ten individuals cited (including Crandall), instead leaves it to the discretion of the President. Unclear if any were gold. ||[[File:Metis Congressional Medal (obverse).jpg|center|75px]] |- | || [[John Horn, Jr.]] || June 20, 1874
April 28, 1904 || 18 Stat. 573
33 Stat. 1684–1685 ||Noted lifesaver. 1904 medal was a re-issue of the earlier award, which Horn claimed had been stolen. Customarily, the Secretary of the Treasury had issued duplicate medals upon the submission of absolute proof that showed the originals had been irrecoverably lost or destroyed. Since such proof was absent in Horn's case, congressional approval was necessary before the medal could be replaced.{{cite web|url=http://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/36538?ret=True |title=The first time Congress replaced a Congressional Gold Medal |publisher=artandhistory.house.gov |accessdate=2014-03-23}} || |- | [[File:John Fox Slater.jpg|75px|border|alt=John Fox Slater]]|| [[John Fox Slater]] || February 5, 1883 || 22 Stat. 636 ||United States philanthropist known for assisting in the education of emancipated African American slaves. || |- | [[File:Inventor Joseph Francis.jpg|75px|border|alt=Joseph Francis]]||| [[Joseph Francis]] || August 27, 1888 || 25 Stat. 1249 || Inventor of life-saving tools. The medal is currently possessed by the Smithsonian. ||[[File:Joseph Francis Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:George W. Melville;h60095.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Chief Engineer [[George Wallace Melville]] and Others || September 30, 1890 || 26 Stat. 552–553 ||To commemorate the perils encountered during the [[Jeannette Expedition]]. 8 gold and 25 silver medals were struck, in decoration form, suspended from a ribbon.{{cite web|url=http://www.numismaster.com/ta/numis/Article.jsp?ArticleId=6630|last= Julian |first=R.W. |title= Jeannette Medal Honors Arctic Seamen|publisher=Numismaster.com |accessdate=30 August 2015}}{{cite journal|title=Medals for the Jeannette Expediton |journal=The Army and Navy Journal |volume=30 |issue=8 |date=October 15, 1892 |page=117 |url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=coo.31924069761728;view=1up;seq=125 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6bPQ3atLm?url=http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=coo.31924069761728%3Bview%3D1up%3Bseq%3D125 |archivedate=September 9, 2015 |df= }} || |- | [[Image:Frank Hamilton Newcomb.png|center|75px|border]] || First Lieutenant [[Frank H. Newcomb]] || May 3, 1900 || 31 Stat. 716 || For heroism as commanding officer of [[USRC Hudson (1893)|USRC ''Hudson'']] during the [[Battle of Cardenas]], 1898. The officers and men of ''Hudson'' received silver and bronze versions of the gold medal. || |- | [[Image:US Coast Guard Capt Commandant Ellsworth P. Bertholf.jpg|center|75px|border]] || First Lieutenant [[David H. Jarvis]], Second Lieutenant [[Ellsworth P. Bertholf]] and Dr. [[Samuel J. Call]] || June 28, 1902 || 32 Stat. 492 ||Participants in the [[Overland Relief Expedition]] of 1897–98 || [[Image:Ellsworth P. Bertholf Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:First flight2.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Wright Brothers|Orville and Wilbur Wright]] || March 4, 1909 || 35 Stat. 1627 ||In recognition of their invention of the airplane and contributions to aerial navigation. || |- | [[Image:Molly brown rescue award titanic.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Captain [[Arthur Henry Rostron]] || July 6, 1912 || 37 Stat. 639 ||Captain of the [[RMS Carpathia]] who rescued the survivors of the sunken [[RMS Titanic]] at considerable risk to his own ship.|| [[Image:Sir Arthur Henry Rostron Congressional Gold Medal, Merseyside Maritime Museum.png|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Paul H. Kreibohm retouched.jpg|center|75px]] || Captain [[Paul H. Kreibohm]] and others || March 19, 1914 || 38 Stat. 769 || For participation in the rescue of passengers and crew of the [[SS Volturno (1906)|SS ''Volturno'']] || |- | || [[Domicio da Gama]], [[Rómulo Sebastián Naón]], and [[Eduardo Suárez Mujica]] || March 4, 1915 || 38 Stat. 1228 ||In recognition of the valuable services of these distinguished statesmen as mediators in the controversy between the government of the United States of America and the leaders of the warring parties in the Republic of Mexico. ||[[File:Eduardo Suarez Mujica,Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Charles Lindbergh and the Spirit of Saint Louis (Crisco restoration, with wings).jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Charles Lindbergh]] || May 4, 1928 || 45 Stat. 490 || In recognition of his contributions to aerial navigation by flying solo non-stop from New York to Paris. ||[[File:Congressional Gold Medal presented to Col. Charles A. Lindbergh.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Nlc amundsen.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Lincoln Ellsworth]], [[Roald Amundsen]], and [[Umberto Nobile]] || May 29, 1928 || 45 Stat. 2026–2027 || In recognition of their contributions to polar exploration. || |- | [[Image:Thomas Edison.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Thomas Edison]] || May 29, 1928 || 45 Stat. 1012 || For development and application of inventions that revolutionized civilizations. || [[Image:Thomas Edison Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:NC4Crew.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[NC-4|First Successful Trans-Atlantic Flight]] || February 9, 1929 || 45 Stat. 1158 || ''See also'' [[NC-4 Medal]] || |- | [[Image:WalterReed.jpeg|center|75px|border]] || Major [[Walter Reed]] and Associates for Yellow Fever Experimentations in Cuba || February 28, 1929 || 45 Stat. 1409–1410 ||''Also see'' [[Walter Reed Medal]] || [[Image:Walter Reed Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Lt com r e byrd.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Officers and Men of the [[Byrd Antarctic Expedition]] || May 23, 1930 || 46 Stat. 379 ||81 people connected with the expedition were awarded the [[Byrd Antarctic Expedition Medal]]: 65 were awarded gold, seven received silver medals, and nine received bronze.{{cite web|url=http://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/36287?ret=True | title=Congressional Gold, Silver, and Bronze Medals awarded to the members of Rear Admiral Richard Byrd's first Antarctic expedition |publisher=artandhistory.house.gov |accessdate=2012-09-09}} || |- | [[Image:Lincoln ellsworth.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Lincoln Ellsworth]] || June 16, 1936 || 49 Stat. 2324 || To recognize exploration that led to U.S. claims to 350,000 square miles in Antarctica, and for his 2,500-mile aerial survey of Antarctica's interior || |- | [[Image:George-m-cohan-1.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[George M. Cohan|George Cohan]] || June 29, 1936 || 49 Stat. 2371 || For contributions to American musical culture through authoring and popularizing patriotic songs in wartime. || |- | || Mrs. Richard Aldrich and [[Anna Bouligny]] || June 20, 1938 || 52 Stat. 1365 ||"Gold medals were given to Mrs. Richard Aldrich and Anna Bouligny some four decades after they served wounded soldiers in Puerto Rico. As part of their 'outstanding, unselfish, and wholly voluntary service,' they set up and worked in hospitals 'for the care and treatment of military patients in Puerto Rico' during the War with Spain. Mrs. Aldrich and Ms. Bouligny 'voluntarily went to Puerto Rico and there rendered service of inestimable value to the Army of the United States in the establishment and operation of hospitals.'"[http://www.usmint.gov/kids/campcoin/medalmania/sciMedAg.cfm Mrs. Richard Aldrich and Anna Bouligny] on U.S. Mint H.I.P. Pocket Change website Retrieved 2012-09-20 May have been the first women awarded this medal. || |- | [[Image:Howard Hughes.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Howard Hughes]] || August 7, 1939 || 53 Stat. 1525 ||For advancing the science of aviation || |- | || Reverend [[Francis X. Quinn]] || August 10, 1939 || 53 Stat. 1533 ||Pastor of the [[Church of the Guardian Angel (Manhattan)|Church of the Guardian Angel]] in New York City. 114 Stat. 622–623 || [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House of Representatives]] [[Dennis Hastert]] and [[United States House of Representatives|Representative]] [[John Joseph Moakley]] led a delegation from the U.S. Congress to bring Pope John Paul II the Congressional Gold Medal on January 8, 2001.{{cite news | last =Staff | title =Congress bestows Gold Medal on Pope.(John Paul II) | work =Catholic Insight | date =March 1, 2001 }} || [[Image:2000 Pope John Paul II Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:The Reagans waving from the limousine during the Inaugural Parade 1981.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Ronald Reagan]] and [[Nancy Reagan]] || July 27, 2000 || {{USPL|106|251}},
114 Stat. 624–625 || "I am sure that each and every one of you have your own special memory of Ronald and Nancy Reagan. I know I do. Many Americans remember how the Reagan's (sic) sparked a renewal of hope and optimism in a nation that was beginning to lose faith in the American dream. This renewed patriotism will always remain one of their most enduring legacies. Ronald and Nancy Reagan shared a remarkable grace, a rare charm that set both the American public and world leaders at lease." — U.S. Rep. [[Jim Gibbons (U.S. politician)|Jim Gibbons]], Republican of [[Nevada]], statement made at award ceremony at Rotunda on Capitol Hill.{{cite news | last =[[CNN]] | title =Ronald, Nancy Reagan Presented With Congressional Gold Medal | work =CNN Live Event/Special | publisher =[[Time Warner]] | date =May 16, 2002 | url =http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0205/16/se.04.html | accessdate =2008-12-04 }} || [[Image:Reagan Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Navajo Code Talkers.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Navajo Code Talker]]s || December 21, 2000 || {{USPL|106|554}},
114 Stat. 2763 || "Today, we marked a moment of shared history and shared victory. We recall a story that all Americans can celebrate and every America should know. It is a story of ancient people called to serve in a modern war. It is a story of one unbreakable oral code of the Second World War, messages travelling by field radio on Iwo Jima in the very language heard across the Colorado plateau centuries ago." — statement by President [[George W. Bush]] when presenting the award on July 26, 2001 at the Capitol Rotunda to four of the five living original 29 American Navajo code talkers, and relatives of the 24 others.{{cite news| last =[[CNN]] |title =President Bush Honors World War II Navajo Code Talkers Receiving Congressional Gold Medal |work =CNN Live Event/Special |publisher =[[Time Warner]] |date =July 26, 2001 |url =http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0107/26/se.04.html | accessdate = 2008-12-04 }}

A gold medal was authorized for each of the original 29 Navajo code talkers or a surviving family member. Silver medals were authorized for anyone who qualified as a Navajo code talker (300+), or a surviving family member.|| [[Image:2000 Navajo Code Talkers Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:General Henry Shelton, official portrait 2.jpg|center|75px|border]]|| General [[Hugh Shelton]] || January 16, 2002 || {{USPL|107|127}},
115 Stat. 2405–2406 || "Throughout his 38 years of service to his country, his ascent through the ranks of the Army, two tours in Vietnam and duty in Operation Desert Storm, Gen. Shelton has carried with him the North Carolina values of service, sacrifice, love of family, faith in God and devotion to country." — U.S. Rep. [[Bob Etheridge]], who helped write the legislation honoring Shelton.{{cite news | last =DeNardo | first =Christina |author2=[[Associated Press]] | title =Congressional Gold Medal: Patriotism embodied | work =[[The Fayetteville Observer]] | date =September 20, 2002 }} || [[Image:2002 General Henry H. Shelton Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Tony Blair WEF 2008 cropped.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] [[Tony Blair]] || July 18, 2003  || {{USPL|108|60}},
117, Stat. 862–863 || "America has many allies, but as we have seen in recent months, we can count on Great Britain to fulfill the duties of a true friend in tough times. I applaud Tony Blair's extraordinary leadership and his continued support of the United States." — U.S. Rep. [[Ginny Brown-Waite]], sponsor of the bill in the [[United States House of Representatives]].{{cite news | last =Solochek | first =Jeffrey S. | title = Brown-Waite backs bill to give Tony Blair congressional medal | work =[[St. Petersburg Times]] | publisher =www.sptimes.com | date =April 2, 2003 | url =http://www.sptimes.com/2003/04/02/Hernando/Brown_Waite_backs_bil.shtml | accessdate =2008-12-03 }} ||{{#tag:ref|It is unclear if the medal was ever struck, or if Blair ever received it.|group=N}} |- | [[File:Jrobinson.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Jackie Robinson]] || October 29, 2003 || {{USPL|108|101}},
117 Stat. 1195–1197 ||"His story is one that shows what one person can do to hold America to account to its founding promise of freedom and equality. It's a lesson for people coming up to see. One person can make a big difference in setting the tone of this country." — President [[George W. Bush]], on presenting the award to Robinson's widow Rachel Robinson.{{cite news | last =[[Associated Press]] | title =Robinson awarded Congressional gold medal | work =[[ESPN]] | publisher =ESPN Internet Ventures | date =March 2, 2005 | url =http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=2002582 | accessdate = 2008-12-03}} || [[Image:2003 Jackie Robinson Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:DorothyHeight Book Nordstrom VA 15feb97.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Dr. [[Dorothy Height]] || December 6, 2003 || {{USPL|108|162}},
117 Stat. 2017 || "She's a woman of enormous accomplishment. She's a friend of first ladies like Eleanor Roosevelt, Hillary Rodham Clinton. She's known every president since Dwight David Eisenhower. She's told every president what she thinks since Dwight David Eisenhower. Truth of the matter is, she was the giant of the civil rights movement." — President [[George W. Bush]], on presenting Height with the award.{{cite news | last =[[Associated Press]] | title =Dorothy Height awarded Congressional Gold Medal | work =[[USA Today]] | publisher =Gannett Co. Inc | date =March 24, 2004 | url =https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2004-03-24-height-gold-medal_x.htm | accessdate = 2008-11-26 }} || [[Image:2003 Dorothy Height Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | || [[Joseph DeLaine|Joseph A. DeLaine]], [[Briggs v. Elliott#Background|Harry & Eliza Briggs]], and [[Briggs v. Elliott#Outcomes|Levi Pearson]] || December 15, 2003 || {{USPL|108|180}},
117 Stat. 2645–2647 || The four filed lawsuits in [[South Carolina]] which helped lead to ''[[Brown v. Board of Education]]''. "These were ordinary citizens who did an extraordinary thing. Their courage and commitment to fight for a better education for their children in Clarendon County, South Carolina, has benefited generations of children nationwide." — [[Jim Clyburn]], Democratic Congressman, helped push the legislation through along with Democratic Senator [[Ernest Hollings]], both of South Carolina.{{cite news|last=[[Associated Press]] |title=Four from South Carolina to receive U.S. medal of honor |work=South Carolina News |publisher=[[WCNC-TV]] |date=August 18, 2004 |url=http://www.wcnc.com/news/southcarolina/stories/081804ccjrwcncscmedalofhonor.8eba5f02.html |accessdate=2008-11-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041113054818/http://www.wcnc.com/news/southcarolina/stories/081804ccjrwcncscmedalofhonor.8eba5f02.html |archivedate=November 13, 2004 }} || [[Image:2003 Brown et al. v. the Board of Education of Topeka et al. Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Martin Luther King Jr NYWTS 5.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Dr. [[Martin Luther King, Jr.|Martin Luther King Jr.]] and [[Coretta Scott King]] || October 25, 2004 || {{USPL|108|368}},
{{USStat|118|1746-1748}} || "Dr. King had a dream of peace and equality and dedicated his life to achieving that dream. Throughout his brief but remarkable life, Dr. King stood for the causes of freedom, justice and equality." — [[Carl Levin]], Democratic Senator from [[Michigan]], pushed through bill in United States Senate.{{cite news | last =Staff | title =Senate passes bill to honor Rev. King and Coretta Scott King with a gold medal | work =[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] | date =October 11, 2004}} ||[[File:Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and Coretta Scott King Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Tuskegee Airmen + US Congressional Gold Medals, 2007March29.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Tuskegee Airmen]] || April 11, 2006|| nowrap| {{USPL|109|213}},
{{USStat|120|322-325}} || "The Tuskegee Airmen were a group of 994 African American pilots who gained fame during WWII for their heroism escorting American bombers in raids over Europe and North Africa. Their distinguished service is credited with influencing President Truman to desegregate the U.S. military." — Congressman [[Charles B. Rangel]], Press Release.{{cite news | last =[[Charles B. Rangel|Rangel, Charles B.]] | title =Tuskegee Airmen Gold Medal Signed Into Law | work =Press Release | publisher =[[United States House of Representatives]] | date =April 11, 2006 | url =http://www.house.gov/list/press/ny15_rangel/CBRStatementTuskegeeBillSigned04112006.html | accessdate = 2008-11-26}}

A single gold medal was struck, to be retained by the Smithsonian Institution. || [[Image:2006 Tuskegee Airmen Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Dalai Lama at WhiteHouse (cropped).jpg|center|75px|border]] || The 14th [[Dalai Lama]], [[14th Dalai Lama|Tenzin Gyatso]] || September 27, 2006|| {{USPL|109|287}}, {{USStat|120|1231}} || In recognition of the Dalai Lama's: "many enduring and outstanding contributions to peace, non-violence, human rights and religious understanding". — (Pub.L. 109-287){{cite news | last =Kaufman | first =Stephen | title =Dalai Lama Receives Congressional Gold Medal: Congressman says leader seeks Tibetan autonomy in China, not independence | work =America.gov: Telling America's Story | publisher =www.america.gov | date =October 17, 2007 | url =http://www.america.gov/st/washfile-english/2007/October/20071017161425esnamfuak0.6734888.html | accessdate = 2008-11-26 }} || [[Image:2006 Tenzin Gyatso Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Byron Nelson by Acme, 1944.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Byron Nelson]] || October 16, 2006|| {{USPL|109|357}}, {{USStat|120|2044}} || "The Congressional Gold Medal is given to individuals who exemplify the American spirit by serving their community and helping those less fortunate, which is what Byron Nelson devoted his life to doing. The lives of countless Americans were touched because of the compassion, dedication and generosity of this great Texan." — [[John Cornyn]], Republican Senator from [[Texas]].{{cite news | last =Staff | title =Senate approves medal for Nelson | work =[[CNN]] | publisher =[[Time Warner]] | date =September 28, 2006 | url =http://edition.cnn.com/2006/SPORT/golf/09/28/golf.medal/ | accessdate = 2008-11-26}} || [[Image:2006 Byron Nelson Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Norman Borlaug.jpg|center|75px|border]]|| Dr. [[Norman Borlaug]] || December 6, 2006|| {{USPL|109|395}} {{USStat|120|2708}} || "The most fitting tribute we can offer this good man is to renew ourselves to his life's work, and lead a second Green Revolution that feeds the world, and today we'll make a pledge to do so." — President [[George W. Bush]], statement at [[Capitol Rotunda]] ceremony.{{cite news | last =Sanner | first =Ann ([[Associated Press]]) | title =Scientist Gets Medal for Fighting Hunger | work =[[The Washington Post]] | publisher =[[The Washington Post Company]] | date =July 17, 2007 | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/17/AR2007071700770.html | accessdate = 2008-11-26 }} || [[Image:2006 Norman Borlaug Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Michael DeBakey.jpg|center|75px|border]] || Dr. [[Michael E. DeBakey]] || October 2, 2007|| nowrap| {{USPL|110|95}}
{{USStat|121|1008}} || "Dr. DeBakey's medical advances have contributed so much to our country and the world. Not only did he perfect the heart transplant procedure which has saved so many lives, but he also invented the M.A.S.H. unit. As a veteran of World War II, he saw our young men dying on the battlefield and was determined to improve medical care to save lives. Dr. DeBakey will receive the Congressional Gold Medal for these lasting contributions." — [[Kay Bailey Hutchison]] Republican Senator who introduced the legislation.{{cite news | last =[[Kay Bailey Hutchison|Hutchison, Kay Bailey]] | title =Sen. Hutchison's Bill to Award Dr. DeBakey the Congressional Gold Medal Passes Congress: Hutchison's Bill will Award Highest Congressional Civilian Honor to Dr. DeBakey | work =Press Release | publisher =[[United States Senate]] | date =October 2, 2007 | url =https://www.senate.gov/~hutchison/pr100207a.html | accessdate = 2008-11-26}} || [[Image:2007 Michael DeBakey Congressional Gold Medal front.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Aung San Suu Kyi.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] || May 5, 2008 || {{USPL|110|209}} {{USStat|122|721}} || "This is a well-deserved honor for a remarkable woman who has led the struggle for freedom and democracy in her country". — [[Mitch McConnell]], then-leader of Republican [[United States Senate|United States Senators]] and sponsor of effort to award the medal to Suu Kyi.{{cite news | last =Schor | first =Elana | title =Burmese detainee receives US honor | work =[[The Guardian]] | publisher =Guardian News and Media Limited | date =April 25, 2008 | url =https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/apr/25/usa.burma | accessdate = 2008-11-26}} || [[Image:Daw Aung San Suu Kyi Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Constantino brumidi.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Constantino Brumidi]] || July 1, 2008 || {{USPL|110|259}}
{{USStat|122|2430}} ||Presented on July 11, 2012 (posthumously). "'An answer to a prayer' is how the curator for the Architect of the Capitol has described Brumid's arrival in this city at the end of 1854. And rightly so...today the Capitol stands, in my view, as the finest gallery of art in the country. The art here doesn't sit idle on display - every day, it summons the building to life and replenishes the soul of the Congress." — [[John Boehner]], Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, excerpt of remarks made at presentation ceremony at the Rayburn Room of the Capitol{{Cite web|url=http://www.speaker.gov/speech/speaker-boehner-presents-gold-medal-honoring-constantino-brumidi |title=Speaker Boehner Presents Gold Medal Honoring Constantino Brumidi |publisher=speaker.gov |accessdate=2012-09-13}} || [[Image:Congressional Gold Medal Constantino Brumidi.jpg|center|75px|border]] |- | [[Image:Edward Brooke.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Edward William Brooke III]] || July 1, 2008 || {{USPL|110|260}}
{{USStat|122|2433}} || "In recognition of his unprecedented and enduring service to our Nation." — P.L. 110-260 || [[Image:Congressional Gold Medal Edward William Brooke.jpg|center|75px|border]] |- | [[Image:ChoctawCoders.jpg|center|100px|border]] || [[Code talker|Native American code talkers]] || October 15, 2008 || {{USPL|110|420}}
{{USStat|122|4774}} || To recognize all Native American code talkers not previously awarded on December 21, 2000, a gold medal of individual design to be struck for every tribe that had members who were code talkers in World War I and World War II. The gold medal representing the tribe to be retained by the [[Smithsonian Institution]], with silver duplicates to each individual code talker.

On November 20, 2013, at a ceremony held at Emancipation Hall in the U.S. Capitol Visitor Center, 25 tribes were honored with medals, with an additional 8 tribes honored whose medals had not yet been struck, for a total of 33 tribes that have been so far identified.{{Cite web|url=http://www.treasury.gov/connect/blog/Pages/Treasury-and-Mint-Join-Congress-to-Honor-Native-American-Code-Talkers-.aspx |title=Treasury and Mint Join Congress to Honor Native American Code Talkers |publisher=treasury.gov |accessdate=2015-09-12}} ||''See'' [[Commons:Category:Code Talker Medals|Code Talker Medals]] |- | [[Image:Group of Women Airforce Service Pilots and B-17 Flying Fortress.jpg|center|100px|border]] || [[Women Airforce Service Pilots]] || July 1, 2009 || {{USPL|111|40}}
{{USStat|123|1958}} ||"Their motives for wanting to fly airplanes all those years ago wasn't for fame or glory or recognition. They simply had a passion to take what gifts they had and use them to help defend not only America, but the entire free world, from tyranny. And they let no one get in their way." — Lt. Col. Nicole Malachowski, first female pilot in the [[United States Air Force Thunderbirds|USAF Thunderbirds]], remarks made at presentation ceremony on March 10, 2010 in Emancipation Hall of the U.S. Capitol Visitor Center.{{Cite web|url=http://www.af.mil/News/ArticleDisplay/tabid/223/Article/119851/wasp-awarded-congressional-gold-medal-for-service.aspx |title=WASP awarded Congressional Gold Medal |publisher=af.mil |accessdate=2016-04-24}}

A single gold medal was struck, to be retained by the Smithsonian Institution. At the ceremony, every attending WASP and a family member of a deceased WASP received a bronze duplicate (bronze duplicates are typically made available for sale through the U.S. Mint) financed through donations{{Cite web|url=http://content.yudu.com/A1npu2/MOAA0610/resources/43.htm |title=Recognition Due |publisher=Military Officer Magazine (June 2010)|accessdate=2012-09-14}} || [[File:WASP Congressional Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Neil Armstrong pose.jpg|center|75px|border]] [[Image:Aldrin.jpg|center|75px|border]] [[Image:Michael collins.jpg|center|75px|border]] [[Image:John Glenn Mercury (small).jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Neil A. Armstrong]],
[[Buzz Aldrin|Edwin E. "Buzz" Aldrin, Jr.]],
[[Michael Collins (astronaut)|Michael Collins]], and
[[John Herschel Glenn, Jr.]] || August 7, 2009 || {{USPL|111|44}}
{{USStat|123|1966}} || In recognition of their significant contributions to society.

"We stand on the shoulders of the extraordinary men we recognize today...Those of us who have had the privilege to fly in space followed the trail they forged...When, 50 years ago this year, President Kennedy challenged the nation to reach the moon, to 'take longer strides' toward a 'great new American enterprise,' these men were the human face of those words...From Mercury and Gemini, on through our landings on the Moon in the Apollo Program, their actions unfolded the will of a nation for the greater achievement of humankind." — [[Charles F. Bolden, Jr.]], Administrator of NASA, excerpt of remarks made at presentation ceremony November 16, 2011 at the Rotunda on Capitol Hill.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/topics/people/features/gold_medal.html |title=NASA Legends Awarded Congressional Gold Medal |publisher=nasa.gov |accessdate=2012-09-10}} ||[[Image:Congressional Gold Medal Astronauts.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:YN3ArnoldPalmer.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Arnold Palmer]] || September 30, 2009 || {{USPL|111|65}}
{{USStat|123|2003}} || In recognition of his service to the Nation in promoting excellence and good sportsmanship.

"Arnold Palmer is a legend both on and off the golf course...His impact on players, tournaments, fans, sponsors, sports television, volunteers and perhaps most importantly on communities where he worked, lived and competed cannot be measured but is deeply felt and will continue have a tremendous impact for generations." — PGA Tour Commissioner Tim Finchem{{cite web |title=Arnold Palmer receives Congressional Gold Medal |url=http://www.pgatour.com/2012/r/09/12/palmer-congressional-medal/index.html |publisher=PGA Tour |date=September 12, 2012 |accessdate=September 12, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120914201201/http://www.pgatour.com/2012/r/09/12/palmer-congressional-medal/index.html |archivedate=September 14, 2012 |df= }} || [[Image:Congressional Gold Medal Arnold Palmer.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Muhammad Yunus - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2012.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Muhammad Yunus]] || October 5, 2010 || {{USPL|111|253}}
{{USStat|124|2635}} || "Professor Yunus set out to do what may be the biggest thing of all, and that is liberating people to seek a better life. And not just any people, but men and women who had only known misery, who had been told they were no good." — John Boehner, Speaker of the House of Representatives, excerpt of remarks made at presentation ceremony April 17, 2013 at the Rotunda on Capitol Hill.{{cite web |title=US Congress Presents Gold Medal to Professor Muhammad Yunus |url=http://www.speaker.gov/video/us-congress-presents-gold-medal-professor-muhammad-yunus |date=April 17, 2013 |accessdate=April 23, 2013}} ||[[Image:Muhammad Yunus Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px]] |- | || [[100th Infantry Battalion]], the [[442nd Regimental Combat Team]], and the [[Military Intelligence Service (United States)|Military Intelligence Service]] || October 8, 2010 || {{USPL|111|254}}
{{USStat|124|2637}} || In recognition of their dedicated service during World War II.

A single gold medal was struck, and it was first presented collectively at a ceremony at the [[United States Capitol Visitor Center|U.S Capitol Visitor Center]] on November 2, 2011. The medal will tour various museums in conjunction with further presentation ceremonies and then be put on permanent display at the Smithsonian Institution{{Cite web|url=http://newsdesk.si.edu/releases/smithsonian-announces-seven-city-tour-congressional-gold-medal-awarded-japanese-american-wo |title=Smithsonian Announces Seven-City Tour of Congressional Gold Medal Awarded to Japanese American World War II Veterans |publisher=newsdesk.si.edu |accessdate=2012-09-13}} || [[Image:Congressional Gold Medal Nisei Soldiers of WWII.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:"A platoon of Negro `boot recruits' listen to their drill instructor (Sgt. Gilbert Hubert Johnson) whose job is to... - NARA - 535866.jpg|center|75px|border]]|| [[Montford Point Marine Association|Montford Point Marines]] || November 23, 2011 || {{USPL|112|59}}
{{USStat|125|749}} || In recognition of their personal sacrifice and service to their country.

A single gold medal was struck, and was presented collectively on June 27, 2012 in Emancipation Hall at the U.S. Capitol Visitor Center. The following day, in a ceremony at [[Marine Barracks, Washington, D.C.|Marine Barracks]], every attending Montford Point Marine and a family member of a deceased Montford Point Marine was presented with a bronze duplicate (bronze duplicates are typically available for sale through the U.S. Mint) financed through donations.{{Cite web|url=http://www.montfordpointmarines.com/ |title=Montford Point Marine Association website |publisher=montfordpointmarines.com |accessdate=2012-09-14}} || [[Image:Congressional Gold Medal Montford Point Marines.jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:September 11 Photo Montage.jpg|center|100px|border]] || [[September 11 attacks|In honor of the men and women who perished as a result of the terrorist attacks on the United States on September 11, 2001]] || December 23, 2011 || {{USPL|112|76}}
{{USStat|125|1275}} || Three gold medals to be struck, one medal shall be given to each of the Flight 93 National Memorial in Pennsylvania, the National September 11 Memorial and Museum in New York, and the Pentagon Memorial at the Pentagon, with the understanding that each medal is to be put on permanent, appropriate display. ||[[File:Fallen Heroes of NY Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]]
[[File:Fallen Heroes of PA Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]]
[[File:Fallen Heroes of VA Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Raoul Wallenberg.jpg|center|75px|border]] || [[Raoul Wallenberg]] || July 26, 2012 || {{USPL|112|148}}
{{USStat|126|1140}} || "In recognition of his achievements and heroic actions during the Holocaust." — P.L. 112-148 || [[File:Raoul Wallenberg Congressional Gold Medal.pdf|center|75px]] |- | || [[16th Street Baptist Church bombing|Addie Mae Collins, Denise McNair, Carole Robertson, and Cynthia Wesley]] || May 24, 2013 || {{USPL|113|11}} || [[Congressional gold medal award to victims of the 16th Street Baptist Church bombing (H.R. 360; 113th Congress)]]|| [[File:Congressional Gold Medal for Victims of 16th Street Baptist Church Bombing.jpg|center|75px|border]] |- | [[Image:1st Special Service Force.patch.jpg|center|50px]] || [[First Special Service Force]] || July 12, 2013 ||{{USPL|113|16}} || Granted collectively in recognition of its superior service during World War II.{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/113/plaws/publ16/PLAW-113publ16.htm|title=Congressional Gold Medal granted to First Special Service Force|author=|date=|website=congress.gov|accessdate=25 April 2018}} ||[[File:First Special Service Force Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:James H Doolittle medal bomb.jpg|center|60px]] || Members of the [[Doolittle Tokyo Raiders]] || May 23, 2014 || {{USPL|113|106}} || "To award a Congressional Gold Medal to the World War II members of the "Doolittle Tokyo Raiders", for outstanding heroism, valor, skill, and service to the United States in conducting the bombings of Tokyo." || [[File:Doolittle Tokyo Raiders Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|center|75px|border]] |- |[[File:Paul_Frank_Baer.jpg|center|75px]] || American [[Flying ace]]s || May 23, 2014 ||{{USPL|113|105}}|| "To award a Congressional Gold Medal to the American Fighter Aces, collectively, in recognition of their heroic military service and defense of our country's freedom throughout the history of aviation warfare." || [[File:American Fighter Aces Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- |[[File:CAP early WWII.jpg|center|75px]] ||WWII members of the [[Civil Air Patrol]] ||May 30, 2014 ||{{USPL|113|108}} ||Honoring the services of over 200,000 Civil Air Patrol volunteers during World War II.{{cite web|url=http://www.amc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123434267|title=Congressional Gold Medal honors Civil Air Patrol's World War II service|work=af.mil}} ||[[File:Civil Air Patrol Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Shimon Peres by David Shankbone.jpg|center|75px|border]] || President of the State of Israel [[Shimon Peres]] || June 9, 2014 || {{USPL|113|114}} || "Shimon Peres has honorably served Israel for over 70 years, during which he has significantly contributed to United States interests and has played a pivotal role in forging the strong and unbreakable bond between the United States and Israel." {{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/D?c113:6:./temp/~c113P0I2g9::|title=Congress.gov - Library of Congress|author=|date=|website=thomas.loc.gov|accessdate=25 April 2018}}||[[File:Shimon Peres Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:Ghent_altarpiece_at_Altaussee.jpg|center|100px|border]] ||[[Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program|"Monuments Men"]] ||June 9, 2014 ||{{USPL|113|116}} ||"In recognition of their heroic role in the preservation, protection, and restitution of monuments, works of art, and artifacts of cultural importance during and following World War II." || [[File:Monuments Men Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- |[[File:US 65th Infantry Regiment.Painting.Korean War.Bayonet charge against Chinese division.jpg|center|105px]] || [[65th Infantry Regiment]] ||June 10, 2014||{{USPL|113|120}} ||The 65th Infantry is the first Hispanic military unit, and the first unit of the Korean War, to be awarded the Congressional Gold Medal.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2014/06/10/obama-honors-puerto-rican-infantry-regiment-with-congressional-gold-medal/ Obama honors Puerto Rican Infantry Regiment with Congressional Gold Medal, ''Washington Post,'' June 10, 2014.]||[[File:65th Infantry Regiment Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[Image:JackNicklaus2006MastersPar3.jpg|center|100px|border]] ||[[Jack Nicklaus]] ||December 16, 2014 ||{{USPL|113|210}}|| In recognition of his service to the Nation in promoting excellence and good sportsmanship (PL 113-210). ||[[Image:Jack Nicklaus Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |- | [[File:Bloody Sunday-Alabama police attack.jpeg|center|100px|border]] || [[Selma to Montgomery marches|Selma to Montgomery marchers]] || March 7, 2015 || {{USPL|114|5}} || "To the Foot Soldiers who participated in Bloody Sunday, Turnaround Tuesday, or the final Selma to Montgomery Voting Rights March in March of 1965, which served as a catalyst for the Voting Rights Act of 1965." ||[[File:1965 Selma to Montgomery Congressional Gold Medal obverse.jpg|center|75px]] |- |[[File:PH constabulary pledge to US and UN.jpg|center|100px|border]] || [[Military history of the Philippines during World War II|Filipino World War II Veterans]]||December 14, 2016 ||{{USPL|114|265}} ||Senate Bill 1555 was introduced by Senator Mazie Hirono (HI) and the House companion bill was introduced by Representative Tulsi Gabbard (HI-02).[https://www.hirono.senate.gov/press-releases/hirono-gabbard-bill-to-award-filipino-veterans-congressional-gold-medal-signed-into-law Hirono and Gabbard promote a bill to award Filipino veterans the Congressional Gold Medal], senate.gov. ||[[File:Filipino Veterans WWII Congressional Gold Medal.jpg|75px]] |- |[[File:Office of Strategic Services Insignia.svg|center|75px|border]] ||[[Office of Strategic Services]] ||December 14, 2016 ||{{USPL|114|269}} ||In commemoration to the members of the Office of Strategic Services (OSS), in recognition of their superior service and major contributions during World War II.--PL 114-269 ||[[File:OSS Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|75px]] |- | [[File:Bob Dole, PCCWW photo portrait.JPG|center|75px|border]] || [[Bob Dole]] || September 15, 2017|| {{USPL|115|60}} ||In recognition for his service to the nation as a soldier, legislator, and statesman. (PL 115-60). ||[[File:Bob Dole Congressional Gold Medal (front).jpg|center|75px]] |} ==See also== *[[Congressional Silver Medal]] *[[Congressional Bronze Medal]] *[[Awards and decorations of the United States government]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=N}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== *{{Cite journal| last=Office of the Clerk | title =Congressional Gold Medal Recipients: (1776 to Present) | publisher=[[United States House of Representatives]] | url =http://history.house.gov/Institution/Gold-Medal/Gold-Medal-Recipients/| postscript= }} *{{Cite journal| last=Glassman | first=Matthew Eric | title=Congressional Gold Medals, 1776-2012 | publisher=[[Congressional Research Service]] |date=January 5, 2012 | url=https://www.senate.gov/CRSReports/crs-publish.cfm?pid='0E%2C*PL%5B%3C%230%20%20%0A |format=PDF| postscript=}} ==External links== {{sisterlinks|Congressional Gold Medal}} *{{cite web |title=THOMAS (Library of Congress) | url=http://thomas.loc.gov | publisher=Library of Congress | accessdate=2007-04-30}} Search for bills and laws. page.title: List of first women lawyers and judges in Asia

revision.text:
This is a list of the '''first women lawyer(s) and judge(s)''' in Asia. It includes the year in which the women were admitted to practice law (in parentheses). Also included are the first women in their country to achieve a certain distinction such as obtaining a law degree or becoming a political figure.
==Afghanistan==
* Jameela Farooq Rooshna:<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iR69DgAAQBAJ&pg=PA10|title=Women Judges in the Muslim World: A Comparative Study of Discourse and Practice|last=Sonneveld|first=Nadia|last2=Lindbekk|first2=Monika|date=2017-03-27|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004342200}}</ref> First female judge in [[Afghanistan]] (1969) * [[Maria Bashir|Maria Bashir (1994):]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AsYztBWM3JkC&pg=PA71|title=Muslim Women in War and Crisis: Representation and Reality|last=Shirazi|first=Faegheh|date=2010-05-01|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-77494-0}}</ref> First female prosecutor in Afghanistan. She later became the first female Prosecutor General in Afghanistan (2009). * [[Kimberley Motley]] (2008):<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/kimberly-motley-the-first-and-only-foreign-lawyer-to-practise-in-afghanistan-a6940576.html|title=Meet the first and only foreign lawyer to practise in Afghanistan|date=2016-03-18|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-04-26|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2016/2/6/the-lone-lawyer-in-afghanistan.html|title=Beauty and the East: The lone foreign lawyer in Afghanistan|access-date=2018-04-26}}</ref> First foreign female lawyer in Afghanistan *Anisa Rasooli:<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OEg8DgAAQBAJ&pg=PA245&lpg=PA245&dq|title=We Are Afghan Women: Voices of Hope|last=Institute|first=George W. ==Sri Lanka==
* [[Avabai Bomanji Wadia]] (1934):<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8jMqAAAAYAAJ|title=Priyadarshini: International Women's Year Book|last=Kiṇīkara|first=Rôya|date=1975-01-01|publisher=Yashodhara Publications}}</ref> First Sri Lankan woman to pass the bar examination, but could not find employment as an attorney [<nowiki/>[[Sri Lanka]]] * [[Ezlynn Deraniyagala]] (1935): First female lawyer in Sri Lanka * [[Shiranee Tilakawardane]]:<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EpwuDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT19|title=Disaster Law: Emerging Thresholds|last=Singh|first=Amita|date=2017-07-28|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9781351593564|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WBW3AAAAIAAJ|title=Human Development in South Asia 2000: The Gender Question|last=Centre|first=Mahbub Ul Haq Human Development|date=2000|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195795080|language=en}}</ref> First female judge in Sri Lanka (upon her appointment as a Judge of the High Court in 1988). She is also the first female appointed as a State Counsel (1978), Judge of the Admiralty Court, Justice of the Court of Appeal (1998) and President of the Court of Appeal. * [[Shirani Bandaranayake]] (1983):<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=50igCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA53&dq|title=Historical Dictionary of Sri Lanka|last=Peebles|first=Patrick|date=2015-10-22|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9781442255852|language=en}}</ref> First female appointed to the Supreme Court of Sri Lanka (1996) * [[Eva Wansundera]] (1997):<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.attorneygeneral.gov.lk/index.php/history|title=HISTORY OF THE OFFICE OF ATTORNEY GENERAL IN SRI LANKA|last=|first=|date=|website=www.attorneygeneral.gov.lk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-03-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.srilankaguardian.org/2011/08/first-woman-attorney-general-of-sri.html|title=First woman Attorney General of Sri Lanka takes oaths|website=www.srilankaguardian.org|access-date=2018-03-02}}</ref> First female to serve as Senior State Counsel, Deputy Solicitor General, Additional Solicitor General, Solicitor General (2011) and Attorney General of Sri Lanka (2011-2012) *[[Thalatha Atukorale|Thalatha Athukorale]]:<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.sundaytimes.lk/170827/news/thalatha-athukorala-countrys-first-ever-female-minister-of-justice-256664.html|title=Thalatha Athukorala country’s first ever female Minister of Justice|work=The Sunday Times Sri Lanka|access-date=2018-05-15}}</ref> First female to serve as the Minister of Justice in Sri Lanka (2017)
==Syria==
* Buran Tarazi Aziz:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://greenpowersolution.org/omar-aziz-a-famous-syrian-peace-activist-64-died-in-custody-february-16-2013-has-it-learned-a-few-days-later-through-his-family-he-died-at-the-h-military-hospital-in-harasta-a-suburb-of-damasc/|title=Death in custody of Omar Aziz {{!}} greenpowersolution|website=greenpowersolution.org|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref> Reputed to be the first female lawyer in [[Syria]] * Ghāda Murād:<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c2tBDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT433&dq=first+female+judge+in+syria&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwitheWM55nYAhUC2WMKHRc9BJ8Q6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=first%20female%20judge%20in%20syria&f=false|title=Islamic Law in Practice|last=Baderin|first=Mashood A.|date=2017-03-02|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781351925938|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iR69DgAAQBAJ&pg=PA237&dq=first+female+judge+in+syria+Gh%C4%81da+Mur%C4%81d&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwik66zE55nYAhUN-mMKHbwhC5QQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=first%20female%20judge%20in%20syria%20Gh%C4%81da%20Mur%C4%81d&f=false|title=Women Judges in the Muslim World: A Comparative Study of Discourse and Practice|last=Sonneveld|first=Nadia|last2=Lindbekk|first2=Monika|date=2017-03-27|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004342200|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thawra.sy/_print_veiw.asp?FileName=26829022120080302213325|title=المحامية غادة مراد.. أول نائب عام على مستوى الوطن العربي|website=thawra.sy|access-date=2018-05-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/programs/womenpioneers/2008/1/6/%D8%BA%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%A9-%D9%85%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AF-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%B6%D8%A7%D8%A1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%8A|title=غادة مراد.. القضاء السوري|access-date=2018-05-11}}</ref> First female judge in Syria (1975). She was also the first female prosecutor in Syria.
=== Firsts in a particular region in Syria ===
* Amna Minni:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://musawasyr.org/?p=1475|title=المرأة السورية في القضاء والمحاماة {{!}} مساواة {{!}} مركز دراسات المرأة|website=musawasyr.org|language=ar|access-date=2018-05-11}}</ref> First female appointed as the Head of the Bar Association in Lattakia [Lattakia District, Syria]
== Taiwan (CHN) ==
* Shi Qiyun:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.laijohn.com/Laus/Lau,KChoan/brief/LauKChoan.htm|title=談劉改造的親戚關係|publisher=laijohn.com|access-date=2017-10-15}}</ref> Reputed to be the first female lawyer in [[Taiwan]] *[[Chang Chin-lan]] (1940):<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1817&dat=19720324&id=zwMdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LZwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4210,4845980&hl=zh-TW|title=The Tuscaloosa News - Google News Archive Search|website=news.google.com|access-date=2017-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2016/09/04/2003654458|title=Taiwan in time: A tiger unafraid of jackals - Taipei Times|website=www.taipeitimes.com|access-date=2017-12-29}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V0ObcOlKeoIC&q|title=China Handbook|date=1970|publisher=Chinese Ministry of Information|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JLrgAAAAMAAJ&q|title=Newspaper Index: Los Angeles Times|date=1972|publisher=Bell & Howell|language=en}}</ref> First female judge in Taiwan. She was also the first female appointed as a Justice of the Supreme Court of the Republic of China (1956). *[[Yeh Chin-fong]]: First female (who served as a magistrate) to become the [[Ministry of Justice (Taiwan)|Minister of Justice]] in Taiwan (1999-2000)
== Tajikistan ==
* [[Oinikhol Bobonazarova]]:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cacianalyst.org/publications/field-reports/item/12811-tajik-opposition-parties-nominate-female-candidate-president.html|title=Tajik Opposition Parties Nominate Female Candidate President|language=en|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/5243eb1f4.html|title=Refworld {{!}} Tajikistan's Opposition Parties Nominate Presidential Candidate|last=Refugees|first=United Nations High Commissioner for|work=Refworld|access-date=2018-02-21|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NFSYcyJULK0C&pg=PA18&lpg=PA18&dq|title=Human Rights in Tajikistan: In the Wake of Civil War|last=Denber|first=Rachel|last2=U.S.)|first2=Helsinki Watch (Organization :|date=1993|publisher=Human Rights Watch|isbn=9781564321190|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cxbkDAAAQBAJ&d|title=Tajikistan: Country Gender Assessment|last=|first=|date=2016-06-01|publisher=Asian Development Bank|year=|isbn=9789292575069|location=|pages=|language=en}}</ref> First female (a lawyer) presidential candidate in [[Tajikistan]] (2013)
==Thailand==
* [[Khunying Ram Phrommobon Bunyaprasop]] (1930):<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FMPGtxUZSjkC&pg=PT243|title=Women's Suffrage in Asia: Gender, Nationalism and Democracy|last=Edwards|first=Louise|last2=Roces|first2=Mina|date=2006-08-21|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-32035-6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x6IOAQAAMAAJ&q|title=คุณหญิงแร่ม พรหโมบล บุณยประสพ: เนติบัณฑิตหญิงคนแรก|last=(Khunying)|first=Rǣm Phrommōbon Bunyaprasop|date=2008|publisher=หอรัตนชัยการพิมพ์|language=th}}</ref> First female lawyer in [[Thailand]] * [[Chalorjit Jittarutta]]:<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TJ7xAAAAMAAJ|title=Asian Women|date=1999|publisher=Research Center for Asian Women, Sookmyung Women's University}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wm3aAAAAMAAJ|title=Statistical Booklet on Thai Women and Men|date=1995|publisher=National Statistical Office, Office of the Prime Minister|isbn=9789742361617}}</ref> First female judge in Thailand (1965)
==Turkmenistan==
* [[:ru:Атаджанова,_Курбанбиби_Сенгреновна|Gurbanbibi Atajanova]]:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rus.azattyq.org/a/gurbanbibi_atajanova_turkmenistan_/24222058.html|title=Взлет и падение Гурбанбиби Атаджановой. Как генпрокурор сидит в тюрьме|website=Радио Азаттык|language=ru|access-date=2018-02-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/russian/news/newsid_4943000/4943878.stm|title=Экс-генпрокурор Туркмении просит о пощаде|date=2006-04-25|access-date=2018-02-22|language=en-GB}}</ref> First female appointed as the [[:ru:Генеральный_прокурор_Туркмении|Prosecutor General of Turkmenistan]] (1997-2006) [<nowiki/>[[Turkmenistan]]]
==United Arab Emirates== In 1991, an unknown woman became the first female lawyer in the United Arab Emirates.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/uae/media-is-best-tool-to-empower-women-says-pioneering-female-emirati-lawyer-1.329588|title=Media is ‘best tool’ to empower women, says pioneering female Emirati lawyer|work=The National|access-date=2018-10-03|language=en}}</ref>
*Khulood al Dhaheri:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uae-embassy.org/news-media/first-uae-female-judge-sworn|title=First UAE female judge sworn in {{!}} UAE Embassy in Washington, DC|publisher=uae-embassy.org|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailyreportonline.com/id=1202552340054/United-Arab-Emirates-names-first-female-judge-in-conservative-Muslim-country|title=United Arab Emirates names first female judge in conservative Muslim country|website=Daily Report|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iR69DgAAQBAJ&pg=PA123|title=Women Judges in the Muslim World: A Comparative Study of Discourse and Practice|last=Sonneveld|first=Nadia|last2=Lindbekk|first2=Monika|date=2017-03-27|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004342200}}</ref> First female judge in the [[United Arab Emirates]] (2008) *Manar al Hammadi:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.emirates247.com/news/emirates/blind-emirati-lawyer-wins-emarat-al-youm-prize-2012-06-09-1.462197|title=Blind Emirati lawyer wins Emarat Al Youm prize|last=Staff|date=2012-06-09|work=Emirates24{{!}}7|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/uae/government/ministry-of-interior-wins-excellence-awards-1.581791?videoId=5587698090001|title=Ministry of Interior wins excellence awards|work=The National|access-date=2018-08-03|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pCdzDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT36&dq|title=Reflections on Happiness & Positivity|last=Maktoum|first=Mohammed Bin Rashid Al|date=2017-03-10|publisher=Explorer Publishing|isbn=9781785960437|language=en}}</ref> First visually impaired female lawyer in the United Arab Emirates * Fatima Al Qubaisi (2017):<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/uae/uae-portrait-of-a-nation-first-emirati-woman-to-join-harvard-law-school-1.168400|title=UAE Portrait of a Nation: First Emirati woman to join Harvard law school|work=The National|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/education/first-emirati-woman-graduates-from-harvard-law-school-1.2062554|title=First Emirati woman graduates from Harvard Law School|last=Reporter|first=Samihah Zaman, Staff|date=2017-07-22|work=GulfNews|access-date=2017-10-02}}</ref> First Emirati woman to graduate with a law degree from Paris-Sorbonne University in Abu Dhabi, as well as the first Emirati woman to graduate from Harvard Law School
=== Firsts in a particular region in the United Arab Emirates ===
* Wedad Huda Azhari Doleh:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/culture/inside-a-pagoda-in-dubai-1.1187169|title=Inside a pagoda in Dubai|last=XPRESS|first=By Habiba Ahmed Abd Elaziz and Jay Hilotin,|date=2013-05-22|access-date=2016-10-05}}</ref> First female lawyer in Dubai [Emirate of Dubai, United Arab Emirates] *Ebtisam Ali Rashid Al Bedwawi:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.khaleejtimes.com/article/20090328/ARTICLE/303289941/1002|title=Dubai’s First National Woman Judge Sworn in|last=(Wam)|work=Khaleej Times|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://gulfnews.com/news/uae/society/uae-s-milestones-in-women-empowerment-1.2270408|title=UAE’s milestones in women empowerment|last=Report|first=Gulf News|date=2018-08-25|work=GulfNews|access-date=2018-10-03}}</ref> First female judge in Dubai (2009) [Emirate of Dubai, United Arab Emirates] * Cynthia Trench (1996):<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/business/day-in-the-life-there-is-a-way-when-there-s-a-will-for-dubai-lawyer-1.204898|title=Day in the life: There is a way when there’s a will for Dubai lawyer|work=The National|access-date=2017-10-03}}</ref> First female expatriate to be licensed as a lawyer in Dubai [Emirate of Dubai, United Arab Emirates] * Ebtisam Ali Rashid Al Bedwawi:<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/crime/dubai-s-first-female-judge-delighted-with-court-debut-1.490386|title=Dubai's first female judge delighted with court debut|last=Reporter|first=Bassam Za'za', Senior|date=2009-07-01|work=GulfNews|access-date=2018-02-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bOkPjFQoBj8C&pg=PA804&lpg=PA804&dq|title=Encyclopedia of Women in Today's World|last=Stange|first=Mary Zeiss|last2=Oyster|first2=Carol K.|last3=Sloan|first3=Jane E.|date=2011-02-23|publisher=SAGE|isbn=9781412976855|language=en}}</ref> First female judge in Dubai (2009) [Emirate of Dubai, United Arab Emirates]
==Uzbekistan==
* [[:ru:Сулайманова,_Хадича_Сулаймановна|Khaditcha Suleymanova]]:<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_SLkAAAAMAAJ|title=Women of the Whole World|date=1977-01-01|publisher=Women's International Democratic Federation.}}</ref> First female lawyer in [[Uzbekistan]] *Mamlakat Sobirovna Vasikova:<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://www.minjust.uz/ru/about/history/|title=Министерство юстиции Республики Узбекистан - История Министерства|website=www.minjust.uz|language=ru|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cNWPLhqvAKIC&q|title=Daily Report: Soviet Union|date=1984|publisher=The Service|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://uzlawyer.com/page.php?40|title=Правовая помощь в Узбекистане: История адвокатуры: "Полувековой юбилей адвокатуры Узбекистана" М.С.Васикова|last=Softmare|first=Negaton|website=uzlawyer.com|language=ru|access-date=2018-06-25}}</ref> First female (a lawyer) to serve as the [[Ministry of Justice (Uzbekistan)|Minister of Justice]] in Uzbekistan (1970-1984)
==Vietnam==
* Bùi Thị Cẩm:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hcmcbar.org/Content.aspx?ItemPK=1|title=Giới thiệu :: Đoàn luật sư Tp. Hồ Chí Minh|publisher=hcmcbar.org|access-date=2017-11-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://anvietnam.net/2016/04/25/tham-quan-bao-tang-phu-nu-nam-bo-o-sai-gon/|title=Tham quan bảo tàng Phụ Nữ Nam bộ ở Sài Gòn|date=2016-04-25|work=An Vietnam|access-date=2017-11-11|language=vi-VN}}</ref> First female lawyer in [[Vietnam]] * Vũ Thị Châu:<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://giadinh.net.vn/xa-hoi/chuyen-tinh-xuc-dong-cua-nu-tham-phan-dau-tien-cua-nuoc-viet-nam-doc-lap-20120901073459962.htm|title=Chuyện tình xúc động của nữ thẩm phán đầu tiên của nước Việt Nam độc lập|last=VCCorp.vn|work=giadinh.net.vn|access-date=2017-12-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=x0pRAQAAMAAJ&q=%22V%C5%A9+Th%E1%BB%8B+Ch%C3%A2u%22+th%E1%BA%A9m+ph%C3%A1n&dq=%22V%C5%A9+Th%E1%BB%8B+Ch%C3%A2u%22+th%E1%BA%A9m+ph%C3%A1n&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzydzyp6jYAhWJrFQKHZ-bDvcQ6AEIKTAA|title=Văn kiện Quó̂c hội toàn tập: 1976-1981|date=2006|publisher=Nhà xuất bản Chính trị quốc gia|language=vi}}</ref> First female judge in Vietnam (c. 1950s)
=== Firsts in a particular region in Vietnam ===
* Nguyễn Phước Đại (1951)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YVWmKC8f_KwC&pg=PA60|title=A Cook's Tour: In Search of the Perfect Meal|last=Bourdain|first=Anthony|date=2010-09-17|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing USA|isbn=978-1-60819-517-6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/142952358/|title=The Pittsburgh Press from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania on August 7, 1982 · Page 11|work=Newspapers.com|access-date=2017-10-19}}</ref>: First female lawyer under the South Vietnamese government (specifically in Saigon, Vietnam) [District 1, Vietnam] * Le Thi Kim Soa:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://i-law.vn/luat-su-pro/le-thi-kim-soa-274|title=Lê Thị Kim Soa {{!}} iLAW - Giải pháp pháp lý thông minh|last=minh|first=iLAW - Giải pháp pháp lý thông|website=iLAW - Giải pháp pháp lý thông minh|access-date=2017-10-19}}</ref> Reputed to be the first female lawyer to open a law practice in North-Central Vietnam [specifically the Nghệ An Province, Vietnam] * Trai Le (c. 1956)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://law.nd.edu/directory/trai-le/|title=Trai - Le // The Law School // University of Notre Dame|last=Dame|first=ENR // Marketing Communications: Web // University of Notre|website=The Law School|access-date=2016-09-28}}</ref>: First female lawyer in Central Vietnam (specifically in Huế, Vietnam) [Thừa Thiên–Huế Province, Vietnam] * Maj. Ann Wansley:<ref>{{Cite book|title=Judge Advocates in Combat: Army Lawyers in Military Operations from Vietnam to Haiti|last=Borch|first=Frederic L.|publisher=OFFICE OF THE JUDGE ADVOCATE GENERAL and CENTER OF MILITARY HISTORY UNITED STATES ARMY|year=2001|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> First female judge advocate in the <u>U.S. Army</u>, Vietnam (1966-1967)
==Yemen==
* [[Shada Nasser]]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-GE8XYd7DEcC&pg=PA217|title=Vital Voices: The Power of Women Leading Change Around the World|last=Nelson|first=Alyse|date=2012-06-05|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-1-118-18477-6}}</ref> (1989): First female lawyer in [[Yemen]] * Hamida Zakaria:<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.skynewsarabia.com/web/article/461522/%D9%8A%D9%85%D9%86%D9%8A-%D9%8A%D9%88%D8%AB%D9%82-%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%AE-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%B6%D8%A7%D8%A1-%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%94%D9%83%D8%AB%D8%B1-100-%D8%B9%D8%A7%D9%85-%D8%B9%D8%AF%D9%86|title=يمني يوثق تاريخ 100 عام من القضاء في عدن|work=سكاي نيوز عربية|access-date=2018-02-27|language=ar}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MJZtAAAAMAAJ&q|title=Азия и Африка сегодня|date=1971|publisher=Изд-во восточной лит-ры.|language=ru}}</ref> First female judge in Yemen (1971) * Samia Abdullah Saeed:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bna.bh/portal/news/84755|title=تعيين اول امرأة فى اليمن قاضية فى المحكمة العليا {{!}} وكالة أنباء البحرين|website=bna.bh|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.refworld.org/docid/4b99011b1a.html|title=Refworld {{!}} Women's Rights in the Middle East and North Africa 2010 - Yemen|last=Refugees|first=United Nations High Commissioner for|work=Refworld|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://marebpress.net/news_details.php?sid=2955&lng=arabic|title=تعيين اول قاضية في المحكمة العليا باليمن|last=برس|first=مأرب|website=marebpress.net|language=ar|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref> First female appointed as a Justice of the Supreme Court of Yemen (2006)
'''<u>KEY</u>'''
* CHN = [[Autonomous administrative division]] or [[State (polity)|state]] of China * ISR = [[Sovereign state]] in Israel
== See also ==
*[[Justice ministry]] *[[List of first women lawyers and judges by nationality]] * [[List of first women lawyers and judges in Africa]] * [[List of first women lawyers and judges in Australia and Oceania]] * [[List of first women lawyers and judges in Europe]] * [[List of first women lawyers and judges in North America]] * [[List of first women lawyers and judges in South America]] * [[List of first women lawyers and judges in the United States]] * [[List of the first women holders of political offices in Asia]] <div class="reflist " style=" list-style-type: decimal;"> == References == <references /></div>

revision.text:
'''Loyal Garner''' (September 28, 1946 – November 15, 2001) was a [[Music of Hawaii|Hawaiian musician]] and ''de facto'' leader of the Hawaiian singing group Local Divas.<ref name="star">[http://starbulletin.com/2001/11/27/features/story1.html "Loyal Divas"]</ref> Her hits included "Shave Ice" from the album ''Island Feelings'' and "Blind Man in the Bleachers" from her eponymous debut.
==Death== Nicknamed the "Lady of Love", Loyal E. Garner died on November 15, 2001, from colon cancer, aged 55.<ref name="Article description">[http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2001/Nov/26/il/il02a.html "Lady of Love touched hearts of many" (obituary)]</ref>
==Posthumous== In 2007 the [[Hawaii Academy of Recording Arts]] awarded Garner with a posthumous [[Na Hoku Hanohano]] Lifetime Achievement Award.<ref>[http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/Apr/27/en/FP704270321.html "Faithful fans of Loyal Garner will enjoy reissue"]</ref><ref>[http://www.nahokuhanohano.org/cms/index.php?page=Lifetime-awards "Hawaii Academy of Recording Arts : Na Hoku Hanohano"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140227155255/http://www.nahokuhanohano.org/cms/index.php?page=Lifetime-awards |date=2014-02-27 }}</ref> On April 2, 2007, [[Hula Records]] re-issued Garner's ''Hawai'i Today'' for the first time on CD format at the request of fans.<ref>[http://hularecords.com/_cart/products.asp?parentID=55 "Hula Records Female Artists"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121034053/http://hularecords.com/_cart/products.asp?parentID=55 |date=2009-01-21 }}</ref>
==Discography==
===Albums=== *''Hawai'i Today'' (1977) *''Loyal'' (1981) *''I Shall Sing'' (1992) *''A Loyal Kind of Christmas'' (1992) *''Sounds of Progress'' (1993) *''Island Feelings'' (1995) *''Loyal Garner'' (1997)
==References== <references/>
==External links== {{Portal|Biography}} * {{Find a Grave|8150116}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2014}}
'''Mangku Muriati''' (born in 1967) is a traditional-style Balinese painter and priestess from [[Kamasan]] village near [[Klungkung]], [[Bali]], [[Indonesia]].
Mangku Muriati, born in 1967, paints in traditional Balinese form, known as Kamasan-style, where the aesthetic form and most stories relate to the ''[[wayang kulit]]'' puppet theatre. This form of painting has a very old tradition, associated with the East Javanese kingdom of [[Majapahit]], which flourished in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries and helped to propagate [[Hindu]] faith across the region – now largely retained in Bali.<ref name="test">[Adrian Vickers, Balinese Art: Paintings and Drawings of Bali 1800 - 2010, Tuttle Publishing 2012]</ref> It was from the [[Kamasan]] village where artists were traditionally recruited to produce classical-style paintings on cloth (or bark cloth) for religious and ceremonial use as well as to decorate the palaces and temples.
Mangku Muriati is a daughter of Mangku Mura (1920-1999), who is considered one of the prominent artists of his generation in Kamasan-style painting [1].<ref>[Anthony Forge, Balinese Traditional Paintings, Australian Museum, Sydney 1978]</ref>
As was common practice in artist families, Muriati used to help her father in colouring paintings from an early age, learning the craft of painting. She studied art at the [[Udayana University]] in [[Denpasar]], Bali, but after graduating, returned to the traditional style of painting.<ref>Adrian Vickers, Balinese Art: Paintings and Drawings of Bali 1800 - 2010, Tuttle Publishing 2012</ref><ref>Siobhan Campbell, Kamasan painting at the Australian Museum and beyond, Art Monthly Australia 2011) No. 244 (Oct): 51-54</ref> Working as a Kamasan artist, she joined a small number of Balinese women who work in this style, customarily dominated by men.<ref>^ Siobhan Campbell, Collecting Balinese Art: The Forge Collection of the Balinese Paintings at the Australian Museum in Sydney, Unpublished PhD thesis, University of Sydney 2013</ref>
In the 1990s, at the age of 32, Muriati became a priestess at her local clan temple in the ward of Banjar Siku. She considers painting and priestly duties as complementary, comparing the role of an artist to a [[dhalang]] or puppeteer, who needs an extensive knowledge of characters and stories, ultimately derived from what is considered the sacred scripture - the [[Hindu]] epics [[Ramayana]] and [[Mahabharata]]. The subjects of her paintings and related commentaries frequently refer to social and political issues in contemporary Bali. [3]<ref>^ Siobhan Campbell, A Balinese artist and temple priest builds on her father’s legacy, Inside Indonesia 106: Oct-Dec 2011</ref>
Muriati’s paintings have been exhibited in Bali as well as internationally.
== See also ==
*[[Balinese art]]
== References ==
{{reflist}}
^ Adrian Vickers, Balinese Art: Paintings and Drawings of Bali 1800 - 2010, Tuttle Publishing 2012
^ Siobhan Campbell, Kamasan painting at the Australian Museum and beyond, Art Monthly Australia 2011) No. 244 (Oct): 51-54
^ Siobhan Campbell, A Balinese artist and temple priest builds on her father’s legacy, Inside Indonesia 106: Oct-Dec 2011
^ Siobhan Campbell, Collecting Balinese Art: The Forge Collection of the Balinese Paintings at the Australian Museum in Sydney, Unpublished PhD thesis, University of Sydney 2013
^ Eric Buvelot, Mangku Mura Muriati regenere la peinture de Kamasan, La Gazette de Bali, Edition de mai 2010
^ Marielle Klosterman, Mangu Muriati Mura, Bali Now, 29 April 2013
^ Anthony Forge, Balinese Traditional Paintings, Australian Museum, Sydney 1978
